It shines a light into what domestic life is like for many Americans. It's an existence that has changed drastically from the days of the Valley of the Dolls to even more deviant and destructive behaviors.    ______________________________________________________________________________________Biographies of AuthorsMaryBeth Neil MaryBeth Neil is an award winning journalist who’s spent more than 20 years covering the biggest events around the globe for American network television. Her writing has garnered her three Emmys, three Cine Golden Eagles, and several 1st place National Headliners Awards. She has produced pieces that drive at the heart of what's ailing America for top networks such as NBC, MSNBC, Discovery, CNBC, A&E, Al Jazeera America and Bravo.Neil has been lauded for her coverage of the Middle East, the MeToo movement, domestic and foreign terrorism and the role of women in the Arab Spring. She has experienced the battlefields of war, and the secret battlefields of family life in some of New York’s wealthiest suburbs, where self-destruction is as common as a luxury SUV.In her debut novel, Neil turns her talent to the silent and unexpected victims held prisoner by narcissists and domestic abuse. She captures what life is like while imprisoned by an abuser, ways victims are drawn in, are controlled and why it is so difficult to leave.  Told through the eyes of a victim, her work will help others understand the horrible, secret life so many partners, and possibly your neighbors, are living. Perry L NusbaumPerry Nusbaum is a dedicated entrepreneur, proven business leader, poet, songwriter and first-time author. Nusbaum’s experience in the business world, as a parent and youth coach directly reflects his core beliefs to empower all those who seek moral enlightenment.  Nusbaum spent the better part of two decades as an entrepreneur reflecting on how his behaviors influence others.  His experience in the fast-paced business world of New York City has exposed him to the underbelly of American greed and narcissism. Seeing the opportunity to re-prioritize his life for his children, Nusbaum drew on the skills that made him a successful entrepreneur and did a complete reset at the age of 48. The details of his journey allowed him to add a unique voice to a story of the rampant abuse suffered at the hands of partners with Narcissistic Personality Disorder, acute substance abuse issues and sociopathy. READ A SAMPLE FROM THE NOVEL: MiA Sample MORE ABOUT THE BOOKThe #MeToo movement shined a light onto abuse in the workplace but has done little to change the sad statistics of violence against women in their own homes. Made in America follows one of the main characters, Sarah, as she easily and unknowingly gets trapped in the web of abuse without an easy escape. Sarah isn't who most people would envision as a victim. She is smart, highly educated, loved and supported by her family and has a successful career.  So how did it happen to her and why can’t she just walk away? The answers to those questions are far more complicated than most Americans realize. With nearly 20 women being attacked in their own homes every minute in the United States, abuse is happening in high end homes in the upper-class suburbs far more often than is talked about. The truth is, no one knows how prevalent domestic abuse is due to the fact victims often keep silent and stay with their abusive partner.  Some victims normalize or don't recognize the abuse. Acceptance and endurance become a way of life. Their day-to-day existence is akin to a civilian in a combat zone. The question in the book is, will Sarah recognize her situation and leave? What will happen to her if she does? Her abuser, like most every other abuser, won’t just vanish if she finds a way to escape his grasp. She faces life and death decisions that abused women are forced to make.​Since America declared the War on Drugs in the 1980’s, with “Just Say No,” drug prices have dropped, usage has gone up and new designer drugs have hit the market. Drugs aren’t just destroying the inner cities, they are ripping apart families of every walk of life. And so often with drug usage, sexual deviance and sociopathic behavior can follow. Made in America’s other main character, Asher, is left helpless, broke and with his family in tatters because of drug abuse. He tries desperately to navigate the system and put all his pieces together again, learning powerful lessons about himself and addiction as he does. His is a dramatic story of struggle, loss and an attempt at recovery.These two broken souls, who have led drastically different lives, eventually find each other in the most unusual way. In the midst of their lives' horror, they battle their own demons as they join forces to try to survive and even find joy in a sea of despair. The lessons they learn along the way are ones that all of America should know. Why write this?Sometimes it’s the PTA president or the soccer coach that has a $1,000 a day drug habit. Fancy cars, job titles and homes are no shield to the insidiousness of addiction. Would you know if a member of your family had an addiction? It’s often those closest to you that you don’t suspect. Made in America will show what happens when addiction is right in front of your eyes without you seeing it. Made in America should inspire a much needed, serious discussion about domestic violence, drug addiction, narcissism and how the three are tangling together and tearing away at the fiber of the country.America needs to take a hard look at its legal system and ask why a woman’s chance of being murdered or becoming homeless skyrockets when she leaves her abusive partner. Instead of saying, “You should leave,” to an abused woman, we should be asking, “How have we failed you making it impossible for you to get out for good?” It is time for a second #MeToo movement, a #MeThree movement, that spreads knowledge about the different types of domestic violence and control being used by abusive partners, how to recognize them and where the system fails the victims. It also forces us to look at the realities of leaving. A fairy tale ending doesn't exist in a world of abuse.  What’s in it for you? Contributing to Made in America will allow these important topics to be brought into the zeitgeist. You will be contributing to a new movement dovetailing off #MeToo. We will use the investment to engage the right literary agent (active discussions with several top notch agents are under way) and publishing house. The goal being at least five major publishers bidding on the opportunity to publish this most-timely work by a three-time Emmy award winner with support from one of the top Public Relations and Marketing Communications gurus in the industry. 5% of all profits will be donated to National Women's Abuse Hotline, Al-Anon and #me3 (once 401(c)(3) status is established!All contributions of $100+ will receive a signed copy of the novel!All contributions of $250+ will receive a "key contributors" mention in the book! Who’s Supporting This Project?Robert Dowling is the CEO of New York-based Hudson Cutler, which a technology-driven marketing and communications firm. He is the former president of PR giant, FleishmanHillard’s U.S. East region and president of Weber Shandwick. Dowling is backing Made in America. Why it's time to act now:
 
Domestic Abuse


One in four U.S. women will experience severe physical violence by  an intimate partner in her lifetime.

One in ten women in the United States will be raped by an intimate  partner in her lifetime.

Nearly half of all women and men in the United States will experience  psychological aggression by an intimate partner in their lifetime

-The Centers for Disease Control
 What is narcissism?Narcissistic abuse is a form of emotional and psychological abuse. It is primarily inflicted by individuals who have either narcissistic personality disorder (NPD), which is characterized by a lack of empathy, or antisocial personality disorder (ASPD), also known as sociopaths or psychopaths, and is associated with the absence of a conscience.-psychcentral.com What is narcissistic abuse?Abuse may be emotional, mental, physical, financial, spiritual, or sexual including:                                 
Verbal abuse includes belittling, bullying, accusing, blaming, shaming, demanding, ordering, threatening, criticizing, sarcasm, raging
Manipulation
Emotional blackmail: Emotional blackmail may include threats, anger, warnings, intimidation, or punishment
Gaslighting: Intentionally making you distrust your perceptions of reality or believe that you’re mentally incompetent
Competition: Competing and one-upping to always be on top, sometimes through unethical means
Negative contrasting
Sabotage
-Psychology Today "There are 304 million persons in the U.S. One in 25 people will have the disorders associated with ‘no conscience’ which include antisocial personality disorder, sociopath, and psychopath. Three hundred and four million divided by 25 = 12.16 million people with no conscience. Each antisocial/psychopath will have approximately five partners who will be negatively affected by their pathology = 60.8 million people!"  -Sandra L. Brown                                                                                                           Founder, Institute for Relational Harm Reduction and  Public Pathology Education Narcissism and Drugs:"Addictive and narcissistic personalities have many features in common...including pronounced lack of empathy for the people around them...They rely on their drugs to boost self-esteem at the expense of the people around them.”        -Joseph Burgo                                                                                                                                                     Author, The Narcissist You Know Just Say No?Every 11 minutes someone in America dies from a drug overdose.
Cocaine is the second most popular illegal drug in the country.
The United States leads the world in cocaine consumption.
After years of falling output, the size of Colombia’s illegal coca crop  has exploded since 2013. The boom has made its way to U.S. streets.
The number of cocaine related deaths has doubled in the United States in the past decade
 Other Ways you can help:Spread the word about Made in America and #MeThree. Follow us on Twitter: @MadeinAmericaNYPost a link to this page on your social media and start the conversation. It's too important to ignore.Also:If you or someone you know is being abused, call the National Domestic Abuse Hotline at 1-800-799-7233. Visit their website at the hotline.org ONLY if you are sure your browser history isn't being monitored. With no judgement, counselors will be able to help you find the safest path to escape and lead a life of freedom.The Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration is a 24-hour-a-day, 365-day-a-year, information service for individuals and family members facing mental and/or substance use disorders. This service provides referrals to local treatment facilities, support groups, and community-based organizations. The number is  1-800-662-HELP (4357).Al-Anon Family Groups is a worldwide fellowship that offers a program of recovery for the families and friends of alcoholics and drug addicts, whether or not the user recognizes the existence of a problem. To find support and a meeting near you, go to the groups website: https://al-anon.org.

story:
My name is Sharrif Simmons

I'm currently an artist in residency at the Open Ateliers program in Zuidoost (Southeast) Amsterdam.

Having cared for my mother over the course of the last year and a half, finding the time needed to write and share my poems and stories was far and few between. It was a difficult period to say the least, but my family and I persevered. My mother is doing much better now. Her particular condition required a different sort of medicine. Not being a family of great financial means, sharing my time and presence with her proved as effective as the prescription pills she was being given. Her physical condition and depression improved enough for me to attend this residency in the Netherlands. My brother now cares for her needs while I'm gone.

The Kindness of Others is not only the title of this book but a genuine remedy for unintended inattention, loneliness, fear, depression and apathy. The last year and a half of my life crystallized how much we truly need each other. Mothers, sons, fathers, daughters, siblings, friends and neighbors, we're all in this together.

This book is a collection of memoir poems and prose detailing my experiences with unconditional kindness at critical times, helping to reshape my world view and inspire deep gratitude for the better parts of our reality, a state of mind much needed today.

I'm asking for an extension of that kindness by helping me complete this book. Any level of contribution will be HIGHLY appreciated. A percentage of funds raised will help victims of gun violence, an all to familiar aspect to modern life.

Please read and share the excerpts I've included in my campaign.

My challenges now lay with me. Over-thinking and writers block can be obstacles to any creative project.

Fortunately, Amsterdam offers no shortage of inspiration. The open Ateliers Residency has provided the space. Please join me on my journey. Looking forward to sharing the poems and stories that make me who I am.

Thank you.

(See excerpts from the book here)

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

“I'd hate to pass through a planet and

not leave it better than I found it."

 

−Sun Ra

 

 

 

 

Prologue

 

       A shaky 9-milimeter pistol, aimed nervously at my forehead, my reaction wasn’t what he expected. It was a calm and plain question, posed in that familiar Black on Black vernacular, tinted with an audible element of surprise; “What you doin’ brotha?” My answer came in the shape of a slug set fire by an elaborate mechanism. His finger pulled the trigger, striking the hammer, igniting the gunpowder, forcing the shell through the barrel, across the air, and into my body.

The bullet entered my shin, instantly disintegrating six inches of my right tibia bone and snapping my fibula bone in two. The velocity of the gun blast twisted me 180 degrees—tearing through denim, flesh, and muscle. My lower leg spun loosely, like a helicopter blade held together by charred tendons and cracked bone. In one eighth of one second, a literal flash in time, my life was separated into two parts, before May 10th, 2007, and everything after.

I collapsed to the ground where I stood. The other four assailants, there were five altogether, kicked me in the stomach and ribs, searching for money, car keys or whatever they could grab. Their next move was debated while I lay next to them; “You killing this nigga??” was the question at hand. Driven by what must have been a natural instinct for survival, I guerilla rolled for several feet, escaping the assault radius and stopping in the middle of 24th St south in the heart of Birmingham’s South Town Projects.

Laying there bleeding, waiting for the shooter to run over and finish me off, I realized my cell phone was still in my jacket pocket. From inside the conspiring circle, someone shouted; “Yo nigga, don’t call the police!” But it was too late; the fuzz was on the way by then. I crawled out of the middle of the road, laid my head on the ground, and waited for the cavalry to arrive.

Oddly enough, as the first wave of pain burned through my leg to the top of my skull, I was overwhelmed by a genuine sense of gratitude. I was grateful the shooter chose to lower his gun and shoot me in the leg instead of my face, avoiding a murder charge and gifting me more days in the life of my son Omari Jazz Addae.

I was grateful my phone was still in my pocket to call the “ambalampse”, had that not been the case, I would’ve have bled out where I laid.

I was also grateful for my super fly, quarter top, Italian leather boots, bequeathed to me by my brother from another mother, musician and fashion guru Mikel Banks. Without them on, my leg might have been blown clean off below the shin, the shoelaces kept the pressure between my foot and ankle, sparing me a worst injury or possible amputation.

Although I'm writing this ten years after the fact, every discussion conjures up cathartic memories of survival, recovery, pain and rehabilitation. Soon after the assault, the support from friends and family, even strangers, confirmed my faith in human generosity, in spite of the mental complications caused by random gun violence.

The Kindness of Others is not only the title of this book, but a truth I've accepted for the better part of the last decade. My diagnosed  post-traumatic stress disorder manifested in different ways. Some more dysfunctional traits introduced new self-destructive behavior, loss of impulse control, and as my therapist put it, financial “magic think”.

Before my injury, I took life for granted at times. A single parent, working poet and part-time teacher, I had no health insurance or safety net to speak of. After 3 major surgeries; a donor bone graft, a skin graft, and a rare procedure where parts of my calf muscle now cover my tibia bone, I depended on a wheelchair, a walker, crutches, a cane, Percocet’s, Hydrocodone, Oxycodone, Tramadol, and eventually human kindness helped get me back on my feet.

This book is inspired by a decade of gratitude for that kindness and the gift of life itself. My son Omari Jazz bares particular mention for his patience and maturity on the front line of my often-surreal road to recovery. Dutch philosopher Soren Kierkegaard stated, “Life can only be understood backwards; but must be lived forward”.

I deliver this in the tradition of Marvin Gaye’s “Here My Dear”, an olive branch and mea-culpa to the friendships I’ve strained. love I lost, and the struggle to be made whole. It’s not what happens in life but how we react to it that defines us.  If anything else, I hope to inspire optimism for the arc of human perseverance and faith in the kindness of others. As we face the world as it is today, keep in mind the words of Sufi poet Attar of Nishapur, this too shall pass.

Enjoy.

 

 

 

              2007

 

 

Never mind.

The self is the least of it.

Let our scars fall in love.

-Galway Kinnell 

 

 

From Memory’s Grace

I was new.

Everything was new.

The smell; a fresh scent in May

Smiles told me things I’d come to understand.

 

Nothing met my expectations, or showed them

To be anything less.

 

They told me it was Magic.

A Magic city.
My son in one hand

New love in the other,

I took in the frontier, prepared for the years.

 

When I was packing for Alabama,

Folding t-shirts, laughing at pictures,

Shredding papers and the past.

 

I was warned of the quicksand of history,

The weight of anger

Distrust and segregation,

Told I might not make it out alive.

 

None of us make it out alive.

 

 Fearless,

Entering the brave parade,

Chest pressed against the unexpected.

 

Not knowing

Just how much of

This New South

I would face.

 

 

Crossing Borders

 

On a walk across the Southside,

Fresh divorce, unemployed, a poet.

Every step washed in humid curiosity.

The importance of change

Leading the day.

 

Across Highland avenue,

Near Bottega,

Down the hill and to the right,

I stop at the Garage.

 

Everything had meaning then.

Broken statues in the bar courtyard,

Ruins of empires,

History and beer.

My poetry,

A declaration of war against invisible borders.

 

I am not the Nigger you think I am

I am not the Nigga you think I am

 

The rebel in me

The student told to say

the unsaid

Write

The unwritten

Live where no one’s living

Agree with little

short of feeling free.

 

Under Vulcan’s eyes, I was tested

Crossing borders built on

Fear and old ways

Empty fences on both sides

 

I am not the Nigger you think I am

I am not the Nigga you think I am

 

Grateful, no one saw me

Coming to town.

 

 

 

Happy Birthday Mothafuckaaah!!

 

It’s March 8th, 2007, my 38th birthday. In typical Piscean fashion, birthdays are holiest of holy days. Most of you Hamburglars remember The B.A.M.A.’s, (Birmingham Area Music Awards) sponsored by one of my favorite periodicals at the time, the Birmingham Weekly. The famed ceremony showcased Magic City’s local talent. A gala affair with red carpets, rented suits, little statues and live performances.

The irony of a transplant from New York getting nominated for a BAMA award aside, I was proud to be competing with local artists like Birmingham J and Thed Weller in the best Hip Hop/Rap category, little ole me, a poet.

Losing the B.A.M.A to Birmingham J came as no surprise. In 2007, his hit track “Move Back”, with the infectious hook “back it on up like a U-Haul truck”, was piping out of radios and clubs across the country, a no-brainer. My award came in a more meaningful moment when Birmingham impresarios Ona Watson and Marty Eagle—may his soul rest in peace—serenaded me on stage, leading a rousing rendition of “Happy Birthday to you” to a packed house in the theater of Birmingham’s Workplay. Founded by Alan Hunter, of MTV fame, the venue was eventually purchased by the Williams brothers, Tommy and Clark, who resurrected it into what it’s become today.

The icing on the cake came when my band performed a set of original music for the pumped up crowd. I was on cloud nine. The validation, acceptance and birthday love, it all made my head feel bigger than a helium balloon at the county fair, straight up, I felt like the motherfucking man.

Of course, all balloons lose air eventually, and the helium filling my head proved no exception. As I was leaving Workplay with my Mother and 12-year-old son in tow, I realized my car wasn’t parked where I’d left it. In the tradition of denial and the river in Egypt, I had a hard time accepting the truth, sending the offspring to further investigate the empty parking space.

At this time in life, my son Omari Jazz was developing an uncanny wit and sarcasm. He walked back over to where I was standing, confirmed the car was missing, and with a straight face tried to convince me he saw Birmingham J take off in it after winning his award.

Accepting my 1987 beige Jeep Cherokee hooptie, bought for $200, had been stolen on my birthday, was a bitter pill to swallow. Standing outside the venue, all angry and paranoid, I filled out a police report as the crowd, who only moments ago was singing my praise, is now staring suspiciously at my situation, all up in my Bisquick. Picking up on my distress, my friend Charity offered to take my family and I home. My good friend former Birmingham City Councilman Jonathan Austin came along for the ride.

Resigned to my situation and grateful for the kindness, we piled into Charity’s SUV and made our way toward Avondale, the neighborhood I lived in before it was redefined (gentrified) by craft beers and fusion Mexican-Sushi rolls. Minutes into our ride home, as we pulled up to a red light on 7th avenue and 23rd street on Birmingham’s south side, what else do we see but my stolen car, casually cruising down the road, a cigarette cocked to the side of the thief’s mouth, completely oblivious to having drove pass the car’s real owner.

To say all hell broke loose in the SUV is an understatement. My poor Mother, bless her heart, was quick to tell me to calm down and call the police. Omari, who hadn’t uttered a bad word since cursing me out at Busch Gardens in Florida when he was 4, let out a well articulated, “What…the…fuck??”

We made a sharp turn and pulled up behind my stolen jeep, following it without the knucklehead’s knowledge. In what sounded like the “Power of Christ compels you” chorus from The Exorcist, Jonathan kept saying “I should have brought my damn pistol, shit, I should have brought my damn pistol”, over and over again, like Marion Barry after DEA agents jumped out of the air vents. This, of course, sent my Mother, who had just moved to Birmingham a week before, into an unbridled panic, repeatedly asking him, “You own a gun?? You own a gun??”

For her part, our stealth detective driver Charity kept her eyes on the prize, never wavering from behind the bandit’s tail. Right when I was about to call the police on my 2007 flip phone, the casual kleptomaniac put the blinkers on, made a U-turn, and started heading in the other direction, straight toward us! Watching this Fat Albert looking mop head—clearly not Birmingham J—driving the car I needed to take Omari to school every morning sent me over the fucking top. In the blink of an eye I turned from mild mannered poet Bruce Leroy Banner into the peanut butter brown Hulk. I slung open the door of the SUV and jumped out.

My plan was some MacGyver shit. I was going to jump on the hood of the car, open the driver’s side door—since I knew it didn’t lock—grab the thief by the throat, and choke him to death while recovering my stolen property, pretty simple.  “If you want to make God laugh, tell him about your plans.” I’m not sure if God was laughing, but Omari damn near split his sides when I jumped out and my arm got stuck in the seat belt’s shoulder strap. Now, instead of sprawling across the hood like fucking Spider Man, I was gliding across the pavement, stuck behind the SUV door, skidding toward my stolen car. I’ll never forget the look of shock and awe on dudes face when we locked eyes and he realized the jig was up. He looked like he was screaming, “Motherfucka, you mus’ be crazy!!” behind his bulging eyeballs.      

When Charity hit the brakes, my arm came loose from the seat belt and I landed on my butt bone, bouncing down the road like an overdressed beach ball. The entire scene scared my poor Mother half to death. Omari just kept laughing like his favorite cartoon Cat Dog had just come on Nick at Nite.

Standing there, bruised ego, sore booty bone, and minor scratches, my car sped down the road and disappeared at the next turn. Having done my best—or at least my craziest—we drove home and dropped off the family. I changed into a Wu-Tang Clan black hoodie and a pair of shell-top black on white Adidas, getting ready for whatever. Back in the SUV, Charity and Jonathan talked me down from the ledge. Rather than search for my car, we decided to stop by Amani Raha, a nightclub in Birmingham’s Pepper Place district.

Amani Raha was owned by my friend Antonio Minnifield, cousin to ex-football star Terrell “T.O.” Owens. The place was a swank lounge for Birmingham’s Black, grown and sexy set. Walking into the venue, I immediately felt better when the DJ shouted me out; being the center of attention always gave me the fix I needed. At the bar, shots of tequila were lined up and we banged them down like Nomads drinking water in the desert. The night was finally taking a turn for the better. Word had spread about my car getting stolen, and my loss to Birmingham J at the B.A.M.A’s, so the drinks and sympathy flowed in abundance. Fuck it; it was my birthday after all, time to celebrate.

About an hour into the party, with bodies gyrating and sweating all over the place, I was invited to partake in the ceremonial “Birthday Blunt”.  Stepping outside to “put it in the air”, we walked out of the venue to a nearby street corner, only to realize we didn’t have the requisite lighter for the task at hand. I waved to Charity who was also outside and asked if she could solve our dilemma. With all the proper ingredients for the consecration in hand, no sooner than I lit the ritual herb stick, here comes my stolen car, the 1987 Jeep Cherokee, tearing around the corner and passing us in a cloud of dust. I couldn’t fucking believe it. My jaw dropped. As the shock wore off, Charity turned to me and let out a loud, “HAPPY BIRTHDAY MOTHAFUCKAAAAH!!” BAHAHAHA!!

I’ll tell you, we laughed harder than I had in a long time that night. Turns out, the thief was joy riding around the South Side before leaving my car stripped and abandoned near the “Piggly Wiggly,” a grocery store off Claremont Avenue in Birmingham. I found the damn thing three weeks later when an acquaintance spotted it in an apartment building’s parking lot, ironically, right underneath a NO PARKING ANYTIME sign.

The year 2007 had shot its first salvo across the bow of my life’s ship. Although I was grateful to have the jeep a friend nicknamed “Christine” back, I could never have predicted the role it would play in the life-changing episode to come a few months later.

From inside the conspiring circle, someone shouted; “Yo nigga, don’t call the police!” But it was too late; the fuzz was on the way by then. I crawled out of the middle of the road, laid my head on the ground, and waited for the cavalry to arrive.Oddly enough, as the first wave of pain burned through my leg to the top of my skull, I was overwhelmed by a genuine sense of gratitude. I was grateful the shooter chose to lower his gun and shoot me in the leg instead of my face, avoiding a murder charge and gifting me more days in the life of my son Omari Jazz Addae.I was grateful my phone was still in my pocket to call the “ambalampse”, had that not been the case, I would’ve have bled out where I laid.I was also grateful for my super fly, quarter top, Italian leather boots, bequeathed to me by my brother from another mother, musician and fashion guru Mikel Banks. Without them on, my leg might have been blown clean off below the shin, the shoelaces kept the pressure between my foot and ankle, sparing me a worst injury or possible amputation.Although I'm writing this ten years after the fact, every discussion conjures up cathartic memories of survival, recovery, pain and rehabilitation. Soon after the assault, the support from friends and family, even strangers, confirmed my faith in human generosity, in spite of the mental complications caused by random gun violence.The Kindness of Others is not only the title of this book, but a truth I've accepted for the better part of the last decade. My diagnosed  post-traumatic stress disorder manifested in different ways. Some more dysfunctional traits introduced new self-destructive behavior, loss of impulse control, and as my therapist put it, financial “magic think”.Before my injury, I took life for granted at times. A single parent, working poet and part-time teacher, I had no health insurance or safety net to speak of. After 3 major surgeries; a donor bone graft, a skin graft, and a rare procedure where parts of my calf muscle now cover my tibia bone, I depended on a wheelchair, a walker, crutches, a cane, Percocet’s, Hydrocodone, Oxycodone, Tramadol, and eventually human kindness helped get me back on my feet.This book is inspired by a decade of gratitude for that kindness and the gift of life itself. My son Omari Jazz bares particular mention for his patience and maturity on the front line of my often-surreal road to recovery. Dutch philosopher Soren Kierkegaard stated, “Life can only be understood backwards; but must be lived forward”.I deliver this in the tradition of Marvin Gaye’s “Here My Dear”, an olive branch and mea-culpa to the friendships I’ve strained. love I lost, and the struggle to be made whole. It’s not what happens in life but how we react to it that defines us.  If anything else, I hope to inspire optimism for the arc of human perseverance and faith in the kindness of others. As we face the world as it is today, keep in mind the words of Sufi poet Attar of Nishapur, this too shall pass.Enjoy.                 2007  Never mind. The self is the least of it.Let our scars fall in love.-Galway Kinnell   From Memory’s GraceI was new.Everything was new.The smell; a fresh scent in MaySmiles told me things I’d come to understand. Nothing met my expectations, or showed themTo be anything less. They told me it was Magic.A Magic city.My son in one handNew love in the other,I took in the frontier, prepared for the years. When I was packing for Alabama,Folding t-shirts, laughing at pictures,Shredding papers and the past. I was warned of the quicksand of history,The weight of angerDistrust and segregation,Told I might not make it out alive. None of us make it out alive.  Fearless,Entering the brave parade,Chest pressed against the unexpected. Not knowingJust how much ofThis New SouthI would face.  Crossing Borders On a walk across the Southside,Fresh divorce, unemployed, a poet.Every step washed in humid curiosity.The importance of changeLeading the day. Across Highland avenue,Near Bottega,Down the hill and to the right,I stop at the Garage. Everything had meaning then.Broken statues in the bar courtyard,Ruins of empires,History and beer.My poetry,A declaration of war against invisible borders. I am not the Nigger you think I amI am not the Nigga you think I am The rebel in meThe student told to saythe unsaidWriteThe unwrittenLive where no one’s livingAgree with littleshort of feeling free. Under Vulcan’s eyes, I was testedCrossing borders built onFear and old waysEmpty fences on both sides I am not the Nigger you think I amI am not the Nigga you think I am Grateful, no one saw meComing to town.   Happy Birthday Mothafuckaaah!! It’s March 8th, 2007, my 38th birthday. In typical Piscean fashion, birthdays are holiest of holy days. Most of you Hamburglars remember The B.A.M.A.’s, (Birmingham Area Music Awards) sponsored by one of my favorite periodicals at the time, the Birmingham Weekly. The famed ceremony showcased Magic City’s local talent. A gala affair with red carpets, rented suits, little statues and live performances.The irony of a transplant from New York getting nominated for a BAMA award aside, I was proud to be competing with local artists like Birmingham J and Thed Weller in the best Hip Hop/Rap category, little ole me, a poet.Losing the B.A.M.A to Birmingham J came as no surprise. In 2007, his hit track “Move Back”, with the infectious hook “back it on up like a U-Haul truck”, was piping out of radios and clubs across the country, a no-brainer. My award came in a more meaningful moment when Birmingham impresarios Ona Watson and Marty Eagle—may his soul rest in peace—serenaded me on stage, leading a rousing rendition of “Happy Birthday to you” to a packed house in the theater of Birmingham’s Workplay. Founded by Alan Hunter, of MTV fame, the venue was eventually purchased by the Williams brothers, Tommy and Clark, who resurrected it into what it’s become today.The icing on the cake came when my band performed a set of original music for the pumped up crowd. I was on cloud nine. The validation, acceptance and birthday love, it all made my head feel bigger than a helium balloon at the county fair, straight up, I felt like the motherfucking man.Of course, all balloons lose air eventually, and the helium filling my head proved no exception. As I was leaving Workplay with my Mother and 12-year-old son in tow, I realized my car wasn’t parked where I’d left it. In the tradition of denial and the river in Egypt, I had a hard time accepting the truth, sending the offspring to further investigate the empty parking space.At this time in life, my son Omari Jazz was developing an uncanny wit and sarcasm. He walked back over to where I was standing, confirmed the car was missing, and with a straight face tried to convince me he saw Birmingham J take off in it after winning his award.Accepting my 1987 beige Jeep Cherokee hooptie, bought for $200, had been stolen on my birthday, was a bitter pill to swallow. Standing outside the venue, all angry and paranoid, I filled out a police report as the crowd, who only moments ago was singing my praise, is now staring suspiciously at my situation, all up in my Bisquick. Picking up on my distress, my friend Charity offered to take my family and I home. My good friend former Birmingham City Councilman Jonathan Austin came along for the ride.Resigned to my situation and grateful for the kindness, we piled into Charity’s SUV and made our way toward Avondale, the neighborhood I lived in before it was redefined (gentrified) by craft beers and fusion Mexican-Sushi rolls. Minutes into our ride home, as we pulled up to a red light on 7th avenue and 23rd street on Birmingham’s south side, what else do we see but my stolen car, casually cruising down the road, a cigarette cocked to the side of the thief’s mouth, completely oblivious to having drove pass the car’s real owner.To say all hell broke loose in the SUV is an understatement. My poor Mother, bless her heart, was quick to tell me to calm down and call the police. Omari, who hadn’t uttered a bad word since cursing me out at Busch Gardens in Florida when he was 4, let out a well articulated, “What…the…fuck??”We made a sharp turn and pulled up behind my stolen jeep, following it without the knucklehead’s knowledge. In what sounded like the “Power of Christ compels you” chorus from The Exorcist, Jonathan kept saying “I should have brought my damn pistol, shit, I should have brought my damn pistol”, over and over again, like Marion Barry after DEA agents jumped out of the air vents. This, of course, sent my Mother, who had just moved to Birmingham a week before, into an unbridled panic, repeatedly asking him, “You own a gun?? You own a gun??”For her part, our stealth detective driver Charity kept her eyes on the prize, never wavering from behind the bandit’s tail. Right when I was about to call the police on my 2007 flip phone, the casual kleptomaniac put the blinkers on, made a U-turn, and started heading in the other direction, straight toward us! Watching this Fat Albert looking mop head—clearly not Birmingham J—driving the car I needed to take Omari to school every morning sent me over the fucking top. In the blink of an eye I turned from mild mannered poet Bruce Leroy Banner into the peanut butter brown Hulk. I slung open the door of the SUV and jumped out.My plan was some MacGyver shit. I was going to jump on the hood of the car, open the driver’s side door—since I knew it didn’t lock—grab the thief by the throat, and choke him to death while recovering my stolen property, pretty simple.  “If you want to make God laugh, tell him about your plans.” I’m not sure if God was laughing, but Omari damn near split his sides when I jumped out and my arm got stuck in the seat belt’s shoulder strap. Now, instead of sprawling across the hood like fucking Spider Man, I was gliding across the pavement, stuck behind the SUV door, skidding toward my stolen car. I’ll never forget the look of shock and awe on dudes face when we locked eyes and he realized the jig was up. He looked like he was screaming, “Motherfucka, you mus’ be crazy!!” behind his bulging eyeballs.      When Charity hit the brakes, my arm came loose from the seat belt and I landed on my butt bone, bouncing down the road like an overdressed beach ball. The entire scene scared my poor Mother half to death. Omari just kept laughing like his favorite cartoon Cat Dog had just come on Nick at Nite.Standing there, bruised ego, sore booty bone, and minor scratches, my car sped down the road and disappeared at the next turn. Having done my best—or at least my craziest—we drove home and dropped off the family. I changed into a Wu-Tang Clan black hoodie and a pair of shell-top black on white Adidas, getting ready for whatever. Back in the SUV, Charity and Jonathan talked me down from the ledge. Rather than search for my car, we decided to stop by Amani Raha, a nightclub in Birmingham’s Pepper Place district.Amani Raha was owned by my friend Antonio Minnifield, cousin to ex-football star Terrell “T.O.” Owens. The place was a swank lounge for Birmingham’s Black, grown and sexy set. Walking into the venue, I immediately felt better when the DJ shouted me out; being the center of attention always gave me the fix I needed. At the bar, shots of tequila were lined up and we banged them down like Nomads drinking water in the desert. The night was finally taking a turn for the better. Word had spread about my car getting stolen, and my loss to Birmingham J at the B.A.M.A’s, so the drinks and sympathy flowed in abundance. Fuck it; it was my birthday after all, time to celebrate.About an hour into the party, with bodies gyrating and sweating all over the place, I was invited to partake in the ceremonial “Birthday Blunt”.  Stepping outside to “put it in the air”, we walked out of the venue to a nearby street corner, only to realize we didn’t have the requisite lighter for the task at hand. I waved to Charity who was also outside and asked if she could solve our dilemma. With all the proper ingredients for the consecration in hand, no sooner than I lit the ritual herb stick, here comes my stolen car, the 1987 Jeep Cherokee, tearing around the corner and passing us in a cloud of dust. I couldn’t fucking believe it. My jaw dropped. As the shock wore off, Charity turned to me and let out a loud, “HAPPY BIRTHDAY MOTHAFUCKAAAAH!!” BAHAHAHA!!I’ll tell you, we laughed harder than I had in a long time that night. Turns out, the thief was joy riding around the South Side before leaving my car stripped and abandoned near the “Piggly Wiggly,” a grocery store off Claremont Avenue in Birmingham. I found the damn thing three weeks later when an acquaintance spotted it in an apartment building’s parking lot, ironically, right underneath a NO PARKING ANYTIME sign.The year 2007 had shot its first salvo across the bow of my life’s ship. Although I was grateful to have the jeep a friend nicknamed “Christine” back, I could never have predicted the role it would play in the life-changing episode to come a few months later.

story:
Travel is the only thing you can buy that makes you richer.

My name is Bonny. I believe that  the best education we can give our kids is to instill in them genuine life-long curiosity about this world and to teach them skills that will help them satisfy that curiosity. Nothing motivates to learn about something more than coming into direct contact with it: when we can see, hear, touch, smell, and taste. And to see, hear, touch, smell, and taste more of the world one needs to get around! That is exactly why I believe that travel is one of the best premises for sustained state of curiosity, and it is important to teach kids from the very early age that we don't just travel to get from point A to point B, but that the journey itself can enrich our lives in a most profound way, given that we are in the right state of mind to glean from every aspect of the journey. 

One of the main ideas behind this book is to motivate both children and adults to learn ''the language this world is written in''. Just like you have to learn the alphabet to appreciate even the simplest of books, so you have to learn tons of background information to truly appreciate any point in space and time and to see how it is woven into the fabric of history. 

Another goal is to educate against prejudices in a fun and engaging way and to celebrate diversity. The more younger generation sees the world as a friendly place the less they will learn to look for enemies, and what you learn as a kid affects what you do as an adult. 

On a more practical note, my aim is to teach the kids through this book how to deal with day to day traveling challenges while we travel around the world with our little hero, Pitomoti!

This book is just the beginning of a bigger project,  which involves a series of books on travel, travelers' club on instagram, educational games, unique water bottles for kids, backpacks, etc. I think it's important to make the kids feel ''at home'' and comfortable when they travel the world. My dream is to create a "travelers' club", so that kids from around the world can communicate through  special ''sign language'' and share their experiences with each other.(More to come on that!)

 

My starting goal is to print a minimum of 1000 copies.

I will need $10,000 for illustration and publication of the first book.

$3000-will be paid to illustrator. (Illustrator-Tatiana Kochan)

$4000-for publishing 1000 books

$3000-for translating the book in English, German,Spanish, French, Swedish, Japanese.

There will also be little recycle bags with illustration, post card, and club membership card which can be used for when kids are traveling to get "Pitomoti points"

If the the goal is not reached I will still use every dollar for publishing this book.

I will be sending emails for any updates on the project!

story:
Gerald Hughes spent most of his scholastic life struggling with the effects of Dyslexia and ADD.

In 2006, Gerald founded the Neuro-Linguistic Learning Center in El Dorado Hills, California. Since then, he has been assisting both children and adults in overcoming a variety of learning challenges, including Dyslexia, ADHD, and Autism.

"Reading with Dyslexia" is the culmination of 10 years of research and success in helping children, teens, and adults in overcoming the effects of Dyslexia. 

The Neuro-linguistic Learning made it its policy to never turn a child away regardless of a parents ability to pay, however, tough times eventually forced the NLC to close its doors. The NLC now lives on thought online "surrogate" coaching programs, and "Reading with Dyslexia", the ebook and the iPhone app. 

This fundraiser is to cover the costs to update and publish "Reading with Dyslexia" in hard copy as well as update the "Reading with Dyslexia" iPhone app to make it easier to use and to accommodate IOS updates. 

Through the NLC, the Reading with Dyslexia Program has already helped hundreds of Dyslexic, Autistic, and ADHD children dramatically improve their reading, writing, and memorization skills by utilizing simple, easy-to-learn techniques to develop their natural abilities and hidden talents.

"Reading with Dyslexia" has been proven to make learning easier, faster, and more fun.

Help us make this highly successful program available to the millions of children who deserve to succeed.

As our thank you for visiting our Fundraising Campaign, please feel free to visit the app store and download the current Reading with Dyslexia app for your IOS device. -- Gerald Hughes

story:
Resumen

Las noticias falsas se han convertido en un problema social. Diariamente circula información de dudosa procedencia, ya sea como campañas negras en estrategias electorales o para causar pánico y confusión.

¿Quién no ha recibido la nota en whatsapp sobre las carnicerías clausuradas porque supuestamente venden carne humana? ¿O la de la camioneta en la que se roban niños para extraerles los órganos? a esto se suma la difusión de memes o fotografías con imágenes descontextualizadas.  Mucha gente e incluso algunos medios de comunicación, contribuyen al caos, compartiendo la información sin verificar.

Verificados Chiapas surge para combatir la desinformación con información sujeta a rigor editorial y a técnicas de periodismo de investigación.

story:
A Study in Publishing

Please allow me to introduce myself. My name is Alexandra; I am a marketing specialist and a passionate book blogger recently admitted for a PhD at the Centre for Research in Marketing and Society belonging to the University of Sheffield. I am planning to focus on the Publishing Market and study the effects of digital marketing on early-career authors, publishing houses and the publishing industry in general. The title of my research is "Early Career Fiction Authors and the Digital Economy: A Critical Review of the Role of Digital Marketing in a Time of Disruptive Innovation” and my goal is to offer an in-depth understanding of how the publishing market works today and the ways in which indie authors can be aided to better achieve their goals.

In search of the Lost Author

The goal of my project is twofold:

  • To study the difficulties that early-career authors, especially independent (or self-published) authors face as they struggle to gain a foothold in the publishing market; and
  • To explore ways that digital media can help them promote their work and transition from independent publishing to traditional or ‘legacy’ publishing houses.

Given the chance, I plan to fund my field research and cover the costs of traveling around Europe to meet with successful and early-career authors, attend book festivals and book launches, interview publishing executives and organize author gatherings to gain an inside perspective of how the market works.

How This Study Will Help Bring New Life To The Publishing Market:

  • Early Career Authors – my study will allow early-career authors to identify and utilize tested and proven strategies that will help them raise awareness and avoid common mistakes when branding their books. This will allow them to break into a volatile and changing publishing industry in a cost-effective way
  • Publishing Houses – my research will bridge the gap between independent authors and publishing houses, thus allowing them to regain some of the market, understand the intricate details of digital marketing and use the data provided to adapt their strategies to the new age.
  • Academics – other professionals will be able to discover the theoretical and practical frameworks of the publishing industry and evaluate the role of social media, digital marketing and online tools in the process.
  • Readers - the study will hopefully lead to an increase in readership in a market still struggling to grow.

Your Help is Invaluable

By generously contributing to my project, you can offer me the opportunity to complete my PhD research and shed new light to the declining publishing industry, inspire and empower early-career authors to follow their dreams and lay the foundations for the future generations of authors.

You can help my project by directly contributing and spreading the word, so that even more people interested in the publishing market can become part of my campaign.

Thank you in advance for your generous contributions and precious time!

story:
The Story—

Old man Oscar insists there's a family in an invisible world called OtherSide that will take in homeless Shin McConnell and her only street friend Dibs Colby. They're convinced he's nuts...until a narrow escape from the police catapults Shin headlong into invisible worlds. There she finds she has enemies out to make her life miserable, unseen Watchers who trail her twenty-four hours a day, and most surprisingly—personal ties to the royal family of OtherSide. But an unexpected encounter in that realm threatens to destroy her trust, and Shin is forced to choose between facing the pain of her past, or rejecting her place in OtherSide.

 

The Author—(that's me)

Hi! I'm Janet Keller Richards, and I've been writing for most of my life—published articles in magazines and newspapers, two self-published nonfiction books, full-length plays and musicals, and more. And THIS PROJECT is my favorite, my passion!

 

 

How you can be a part of it

The process of contributing to my campaign is very simple: on the right side of this campaign page, find a reward tier that interests you: hover over it with your cursor and click on "GET THIS PERK." It's that simple! Rewards range from a very cool bookmark or an eye-catching fridge magnet of the book's front cover, to your own signed copy of the book or a beautiful handmade picnic basket, or helping Third World families move out of poverty.

On the higher reward tiers of this campaign, through Heifer International you'll be helping third world families move out of poverty and into self-sustaining lifestyles. Heifer International is a global nonprofit organization working to eradicate poverty and hunger through sustainable, values-based holistic community development. Purchasing shares in the purchases of goats, sheep, pigs, flocks of chicks, water buffaloes, and heifers is like giving them a small business, providing wool, milk, eggs and more. Animal donations can provide these families a hand up, giving increasing access to medicine, school, food and more. On some of the reward tiers of this campaign, there are opportunities to give toward purchasing all of the animals mentioned previously...and help impoverished families!

 

What We Need & What You Get

The book is already written, so you won't have to wait for a long time to get your rewards. As soon as the Indiegogo campaign is completed it will go to print, and I expect that all rewards will be fulfilled within a month or two after the books are shipped to me.

  • $7,000.00 will enable the printing of 1500 paperback books, 352 pages in length. In addition to printing the books, that amount also includes formatting and design costs, freight costs to ship the books to storage, postage and packaging material for the rewards, Indiegogo fees and credit card/Paypal processing fees.
  • If you help me reach the campaign goal of $7,000.00 I'll celebrate until the cows come home (and then get busy printing the books and sending off your rewards)!

 

The Impact

A wise man in Italy once said, "ART SPEAKS TO THE HEART." We've all watched a good movie that moved us to tears, or read a great story that filled us with hope. STORIES can change us, heal us, and give us food for thought. The Other Side Of Visible is a such a book. I invite your contribution to art that will speak to the heart of its readers.

 

Challenges

For the last number of years my husband and I have been serving in France and Europe to better people's lives through training and informal counseling, and we don't have the means to do a print run of this size on our own. That's why we're inviting your help.

And just FYI, throughout the last twelve years, I've successfully launched the printing and self-publishing of two books, so I know what it takes and I'm committed to following through.

 

Help by Spreading The Word!

You can also help me by SHARING, SHARING, SHARING, on social media. Use Indiegogo's "Share" tools and feel free to plaster this campaign all over your social media, or by email, etc! If you do, I'll do my living room happy dance...and maybe even video it for Facebook. And THAT is something you don't want to miss.

 

DOWNLOAD a PDF FILE to read THE FIRST FEW CHAPTERS

of The Other Side Of Visible, absolutely FREE:

http://www.janetkellerrichards.com/the-other-side-of-visible

story_txt:
The Story—
Old man Oscar insists there's a family in an invisible world called OtherSide that will take in homeless Shin McConnell and her only street friend Dibs Colby. They're convinced he's nuts...until a narrow escape from the police catapults Shin headlong into invisible worlds. There she finds she has enemies out to make her life miserable, unseen Watchers who trail her twenty-four hours a day, and most surprisingly—personal ties to the royal family of OtherSide. But an unexpected encounter in that realm threatens to destroy her trust, and Shin is forced to choose between facing the pain of her past, or rejecting her place in OtherSide.
 
The Author—(that's me)

Hi! I'm Janet Keller Richards, and I've been writing for most of my life—published articles in magazines and newspapers, two self-published nonfiction books, full-length plays and musicals, and more. And THIS PROJECT is my favorite, my passion!
 

 
How you can be a part of it
The process of contributing to my campaign is very simple: on the right side of this campaign page, find a reward tier that interests you: hover over it with your cursor and click on "GET THIS PERK." It's that simple! Rewards range from a very cool bookmark or an eye-catching fridge magnet of the book's front cover, to your own signed copy of the book or a beautiful handmade picnic basket, or helping Third World families move out of poverty.


On the higher reward tiers of this campaign, through Heifer International you'll be helping third world families move out of poverty and into self-sustaining lifestyles.  Heifer International is a global nonprofit organization working to eradicate poverty and hunger through sustainable, values-based holistic community development. Purchasing shares in the purchases of goats, sheep, pigs, flocks of chicks, water buffaloes, and heifers is like giving them a small business, providing wool, milk, eggs and more. Animal donations can provide these families a hand up, giving increasing access to medicine, school, food and more. On some of the reward tiers of this campaign, there are opportunities to give toward purchasing all of the animals mentioned previously...and help impoverished families!

 
What We Need & What You Get
The book is already written, so you won't have to wait for a long time to get your rewards. As soon as the Indiegogo campaign is completed it will go to print, and I expect that all rewards will be fulfilled within a month or two after the books are shipped to me.


$7,000.00 will enable the printing of 1500 paperback books, 352 pages in length. In addition to printing the books, that amount also includes formatting and design costs, freight costs to ship the books to storage, postage and packaging material for the rewards, Indiegogo fees and credit card/Paypal processing fees.
If you help me reach the campaign goal of $7,000.00 I'll celebrate until the cows come home (and then get busy printing the books and sending off your rewards)!

 


The Impact
A wise man in Italy once said, "ART SPEAKS TO THE HEART." We've all watched a good movie that moved us to tears, or read a great story that filled us with hope. STORIES can change us, heal us, and give us food for thought. The Other Side Of Visible is a such a book. I invite your contribution to art that will speak to the heart of its readers.
 

Challenges
For the last number of years my husband and I have been serving in France and Europe to better people's lives through training and informal counseling, and we don't have the means to do a print run of this size on our own. That's why we're inviting your help.
And just FYI, throughout the last twelve years, I've successfully launched the printing and self-publishing of two books, so I know what it takes and I'm committed to following through.
 


Help by Spreading The Word!
You can also help me by SHARING, SHARING, SHARING, on social media. Use Indiegogo's "Share" tools and feel free to plaster this campaign all over your social media, or by email, etc! If you do, I'll do my living room happy dance...and maybe even video it for Facebook. And THAT is something you don't want to miss.
 
DOWNLOAD a PDF FILE to read THE FIRST FEW CHAPTERS
of The Other Side Of Visible, absolutely FREE:

http://www.janetkellerrichards.com/the-other-side-of-visible   
OR, go to my blog at: http://www.janetkellerrichards.com/blog to read these chapters online.

story:
Scott D. Van Orden/Story Artist

Everyone loves a good story, filled with fun characters and crazy complications. Communicating a great story through a sequence of images is a lot of fun for me. It can be challenging and very rewarding. 'Other Worlds' is only a step in that direction for me. This is my third book and it humbles me to create a book that is so much bigger then me. I enjoy learning as I go and every new book is filled with obstacles and sometimes roadblocks. I can't count the number of times I wanted to give up on this project. Fairies and monsters, goblins and aliens, it's all in this coloring book.

It's time for some help. I have all these great characters living in their complicated environments. Compiled together to help you relieve stress by coloring them.

Your donation will help me make this book a reality. A fantasy coloring book can become a reality.

What a concept! Thank you so much for contributing. I promise to give you a fantastical book, filled with hours of coloring enjoyment. 

What I Need & What You Get?

I need some money to make this a reality and you can help with that.

Design time, editing and printing costs are all factors in the creation of this book.

Here's a look at the prototype of 'Other Worlds: Adult Sized Coloring Book'.

I set up a three tier system of donations for you to consider. Look each one over and decide which perks package best suites you. You can help fund this campaign in several ways.

Maybe you don't want a coloring book, but think this idea is pretty cool. Go ahead and tell all your friends. Word of mouth and sharing this project helps me too! Indiegogo has social tools for sharing. Please help me spread the word.

Maybe you want more than just a coloring book. I'm offering some fun bonus items for you. This part of campaigning is always fun for me. I enjoy offering fun, little perks with my books.

Studies prove that coloring relieves the stresses of everyday life. I want this coloring book to relax you. Everyone has memories of coloring in a coloring book. Let's make some more memories together.

I want to hear from you after this campaign is over and you started coloring in your new coloring book. I want to see all the color and effort you will be investing in this wacky book. Reach out to me and let me know what you think. I want to hear from everyone. You are the people that will make this book a reality. 

I'll be providing you with updates about the campaign. Final page edits. Deadlines and other goals that will happen for us along the way. I want you to be involved and informed, along the way.

As a story teller and artist, I want to create a coloring book for us both to be proud of. Filled with pages of wonder. The cool thing about a coloring book project is you get to complete the story. My black and white pages are the backbone to your creative, color palette. It's your coloring techniques that will complete the stories in this book.

I look forward to making a great project with you.

Let's make this fantasy book a reality!

Stay outside the lines friends and thank you, for all the encouragement and support.

story:
UPDATE!!! The book has changes a bit and is now being printed in landscape. The book is going to be much better this way! To see book specs and still order an autographed copy this book from the author, please click the link here - ANDERSROSEBERGBOOKS or visit www.andersrosebergbooks.wordpress.com

has just arrived in town! Everyone's invited on a spectacular ride through the memory of rare vintage circus illustrations in this fun, even comical read.

***a hardback mockup

Hello, Indiegogo World! I'm Anders Roseberg, children's book author. I've been working with children for roughly 12 years. I also love vintage memorabilia, antiques, rare photographs, and I absolutely love the feel of the circus life back in the 1900's. That's why I am excited about our new project, The Wondrous Wandering Acrobats Show.

We understand the worries of what animal roles are in the book. Rest assured, there are NO pages that showcase any cruelty towards animals. In fact, other than horseback riding, any animals in the book are more like the human acrobats in the book. They can move freely, do stunts, or talk. No cages, no whips.

Take a look below at what we're doing in a nutshell. Here's a close look at an original illustrated poster dated 1898 - 

A touch of magic! Bipiti, bopiti, boo! Retouched and edited.

And now the full page spread with story

 

As you can see from the sample above, the illustrations seem to climb out of the page so to speak. 

Here's another example of the train chugging out of the illustration.

Supporting our campaign is a wonderful chance to share the history of the circus, but also, helps preserve and restore these collected images for the generations now and generations to come in a fun-to-read story! Most of these images have been lost and forgotten. Some are over 100 years old!

As a contributor, you can help us achieve our funding goal by getting The Wondrous Traveling Acrobats Show retouched and edited into full and half page spreads, traditionally printed and bound, and delivered to the imaginations of children, and in the hands of vintage circus lovers all over the globe!

To get the ball rolling, we're shooting for a modest goal of 2,500 USD. This is a list of where the pledges will go.

 

  • A Traditional Printed Book with Traditional Binding (42%) 
  •  Shipping Books (25%) 
  •  Editing, Design, Proofing, Finishing (10%) 
  •  Marketing (10%) 
  •  Campaign Fees (5%) 
  •  ISBN Numbers Fees, and Dues (2%) 

We have a variety of different perks ranging from a $3 e-book format of your choosing or a 32-page traditionally printed and bound hardback book. We have some freebies for exceeding our goal, but it will depend on how much buzz for The Wondrous Wandering Acrobats Show we can get.

***a hardback mock-up

  • 32 page book with spreads and half spreads 
  • 8.5 X 11 inches closed 
  • hardback for long lasting 
  • high quality and traditionally printed and bound 
  • unique illustrations on every page that open imaginations and discussions 
  • large 16 pt reading font 
  • ending "Author's Note" about the book and brief history of circuses
  • rhythmic story that teaches vocabulary in a fun "tongue twister" way

The vastly different illustrations will mesmerize and because of the witty rhyming, it's super catchy and fun. Whether it's learning new vocabulary, learning the rhythm and rhyme, or just enjoying the illustrations, kids catch something new, each time they read it!  

***a paperback mockup

Some of the images are edited around the exciting story. For example, on this page it reads, "The steam engine is ready. Big tents are coming down..." You can see that the old original image has tents upright. Now take a look at the edited image which has the top part of the tent coming down! 

The Wondrous Wandering Acrobats Show is an important piece of a collected lost history. These rare circus posters have been gathered, collected, edited and brought together in a fun, exciting, and even hilarious story. This book is literally history at the fingertips. With successful funding, you can pat yourselves on the back for bringing a light to a lost, hidden past, that was sitting in a dark vault for almost a century.

This may be the first and last time to get this collection of vintage circus posters under one cover and with such a story to accommodate them. 

Well that would be fantastic, wouldn't it!

After we exceed our goal, the first thing I want to do is include an audiobook free with every reward! It would be great to have the backers help pick a great voice actor and discuss the music! Audiobooks are great for listening comprehension as well as a good guide to help early readers. They're great on longer drives and fantastic before bed. 

Let's focus on hitting that goal and getting the free audiobook. Then we'll roll out some stretch goals.

In the event we don't reach our goal, funds will go towards the printing, and I'll have to seek funding elsewhere. Those from the Indiegogo world who contributed will still get their reward but it may not be possible for such a special and unique binding option and the free audiobook would NOT be included. That's why it's important to share this amazing opportunity!

Children need to read. It's an important milestone in a child's life. Not just for this book, but reading to a child in general is very important. Let's give kids around the globe that same opportunity with a one of a kind,  unique, fun, imaginative book. Here's a few reasons why childhood reading is important:   

  •  It stimulates imagination and can expand their understanding about the world we live in. 
  •  Book time can provide a quiet and calm time.
  • A book like this opens the door for discussion for the curious.
  • Reading books can also teach print concepts of the rules of reading. (up down, left to right) 
  •  It teaches language skills and opens a door to new vocabulary. 
  • Teaches an appreciation for art and the art of writing. 
  •  It allows a time for parent and child to bond. 
  •  It gives room to imagination and play!   

Thanks for taking a look at our project. We are asking for your support by choosing a perk of your choice and contributing. That being said, if you'd like to help bring The Wondrous Wandering Acrobats Show to life but you don't have the funds to help now, you can also help by sharing this crowdfunding link  on your social media walls and help create a buzz.  You never know how far your Facebook link or tweet may go, so please help spread this campaign where you can!   

Thank you so much for your generous support!  

Anders Roseberg  

Author of The Wondrous Wandering Acrobats Show 

www.andersrosebergbooks.wordpress.com

story:
Short Summary:

First off, I am not a professional writer; I am a law enforcement professional that happens to be a conservative millennial....that also likes to write. I have developed a sense of where my profession is going, and how my generation will improve it. Millennials have developed a poor reputation amongst other generations, but there are those of us that are ready to take the reins of an entire profession to begin fixing it. Criminal Justice reform is nothing new, and books on the topic aren't new either, but how my generation can start fixing it, is. This book will cover topics such as understanding the millennial officer, prison overcrowding, the devaluation of the criminal justice degree, data-driven analytics, substance abuse, victim-centered approaches, dynamic search warrants, predictive policing, and other hot topics as we move into the future. It takes money for cover art, editing, publishing, etcetera. That's why I am asking for your help, and hope you can back my project. 

 

What We Need:

I am raising funds to provide the best product possible to get these pragmatic approaches into as many hands as possible. These funds will go towards book cover design, audio, editing, publishing, etcetera. 

The Impact

Very soon the millennial generation will be in charge, period. Whether that scares the hell out of you or not, doesn't matter, it's coming. Now, we as millennials can continue to be perceived as the whiniest and laziest generation there has ever been or....we can show the world that we are the most educated and technologically advanced generation in the world. Not only are we going to run the Criminal Justice system, but we are also going to take it to a height most never thought possible. It is time for a collective group of millennial, professional, criminal justice practitioners, to begin emerging with innovative ideas and practicality that can change the world.

Criminal Justice reform is nothing new, and books on the topic aren't new either, but how my generation can start fixing it, is. This book will cover topics such as understanding the millennial officer, prison overcrowding, the devaluation of the criminal justice degree, data-driven analytics, substance abuse, victim-centered approaches, dynamic search warrants, predictive policing, and other hot topics as we move into the future. It takes money for cover art, editing, publishing, etcetera. That's why I am asking for your help, and hope you can back my project. 
 

What We Need:
I am raising funds to provide the best product possible to get these pragmatic approaches into as many hands as possible. These funds will go towards book cover design, audio, editing, publishing, etcetera. 

The Impact
Very soon the millennial generation will be in charge, period. Whether that scares the hell out of you or not, doesn't matter, it's coming. Now, we as millennials can continue to be perceived as the whiniest and laziest generation there has ever been or....we can show the world that we are the most educated and technologically advanced generation in the world. Not only are we going to run the Criminal Justice system, but we are also going to take it to a height most never thought possible. It is time for a collective group of millennial, professional, criminal justice practitioners, to begin emerging with innovative ideas and practicality that can change the world.

story:
Thank you for visiting our crowdfunding page !

 

Here is the story of "The Silk Road revisited..."

This exciting new book, "The Silk Road Revisited", by Nick Rowan invites us to take an astonishing cultural journey throughout Europe, Central Asia and China along one of the world’s oldest trading routes. Take an exhilarating voyage from the comfort of your armchair and find out more about the history, culture and traditions of each country while marveling at the exquisite accompanying photography.  

This is no ordinary book on history – it is a personal view of the Silk Road’s fascinating history that has made each country that once lined its route what it is today. Charting a course from West to East, the book deviates from the traditional East to West depiction of the Silk Road. The engaging text is complimented by captivating photography as the reader travels from charming and powerful Venice to the homeland of the Yellow Dragon, China, from snow-capped mountains of Kyrgyzstan to the vast steppes of Kazakhstan and from the fearless Turkic tribes to the noble Persian empires. Each chapter the reader also encounters the diverse peoples, delicious cuisine and delightful landscapes.

Traveling through the pages of the book, the reader seamlessly moves from the familiar world of Europe to the less familiar territories of Central Asia and the mystique of the East. The book captures attention with its elegant design, cultural charm and unfurls like an unsolved mystery. Venice, Turkey, Persia, Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Kyrgyzstan, Turkmenistan, Tajikistan, and China - The Great Silk Road once united countries, empires and religions. Common goals and one soul, meant often melted away the differences in culture, language and the distance between them.

 

You can now pre-order your copy today! And for those who wish to sponsor the book there are additional bonuses!

By pre-ordering and sponsoring the book you will get the following benefits depending on which perk you select:

  1. Your name mentioned in a special ‘Thank You’ page as a way of expressing our gratitude for your help (Sponsors & all pre-orders)
  2. Your own personalised signed copy of Silk Road Revisited (All pre-orders)
  3. The latest issue of the only magazine in English in the world about Central Asia - "OCA Magazine" (Sponsors & all pre-orders)
  4. You will get a free issue of the magazine "Discovery Central Asia" (All pre-orders)
  5. You will get a signed copy of the Nick Rowan's first book "Friendly Steppes: A Silk Road Journey" as a gift! (Author Collection Perk)

We happy to offer you following opportunities to get involved:
1. Pre-order signed copy of the book on Indiegogo available until 25/07/2020
2. Make bulk pre-order (via email) until  1/09/2020
3. Place your advert inside book (last 8 pages) only available until 1/08/2020
4. Arrange author talk in UK, starting from 1/09/2020 (subject to availability)

About the author :

Nick Rowan is editor-in-chief of the UK published magazine, Open Central Asia, and author of “Friendly Steppes: A Silk Road Journey” that recounts his travel adventures along the Silk Road, Nick Rowan has an insatiable appetite for all things Central Asian. An Oxford University graduate, now working in the Oil industry for Shell in London, Nick spends much of his spare time exploring Central Asia, having travelled to all the countries on numerous occasions, his latest adventure spent two weeks tracking the Pamir Highway. His new book, The Silk Road Revisited, seeks to capture the powerful influence that the history of the Silk Road has left on the countries as you find them today.

Our Photographers 

The Silk Road Revisited represents the work of photojournalists who have - and continue to - document stories. These photographers are the heroes who work globally to investigate and reveal cultures. Their exhaustive and in-depth work has resulted in some of the most compelling and historic images of street, buildings and landscapes that we have seen. Among them are Feruz Rustamov, Mukhhiddin A Lee, Dovlet Madadov, Eduard Kamenskih, James Stronsky, Zeinulla Kakimzhanov, Nina V. Belomestnova, Pavel Svoboda, Dan Lundberg & others.

Supporting this worldwide book

BOOK SPECS:

144 Pages

Approximately 200 historic and modern images

4-colour printing

Size: 203 * 203

Cover: glossy

Printed on sustainably sourced paper

Selling Price: £ 30 

When you purchase your copy of "The Silk Road revisited" or one of our perks, you’ll be helping us to reach our crowdfunding goal of £ 2500. Our funding tiers start with the purchase of one book and end with opportunities to become Publishing Parther.

Our costs include: 

-Printing! We will be printing a limited edition run of 1000 copies 

- Book shipping (free in UK) and environmentally friendly packaging 

-Distribution

-Advertising and PR

-Travel costs and overhead for conferences to present the book globally in 2020 and beyond

-The people working to realise this book: the time of the co-editors, the designer, the colour editor, the project manager, team working on design, copy, social media, and video production for this book.

 

Please help us spread the word!

We know that not everyone can contribute, especially with the recent Covid 19 upheaval, and not everyone travels! For those itching to travel but who can’t right now, this book will help you plan your next adventure. And even if you can't contribute directly, we hope that you can perhaps share our project with the travel lovers in your life through the Indiegogo tools here.

Thank you for your continued support!

With gratitude and resilience,

Nick Rowan
