story:
Meet Zachary & Cardinal Chronicles 

Hi! My name is Zachary Allen and I am the Founder and President of Cardinal Chronicles. Born in Charlotte, North Carolina, I grew up in the nearby town of Indian Trail, and have called North Carolina home my entire life. Currently, I am a Junior at East Carolina University (Go Pirates!), and am working towards a Bachelor of Arts in Political Science. 

Today, you are reading the cliff-notes of a company and product that was designed and built to inspire and empower those who call the Old North State home. Our product is simple: we want to create a magazine publication that provides its readers with four simple items:

Number one: a way of keeping up-to-date with all the political, social and economic news that is relevant to their corner of the world. We do this by empowering and utilizing local and regional news sources to give you the details on issues that truly matter to your life and livelihood.

Number two: providing you with the information needed to identify, and keep reported on the actions and inactions of your political representatives. This will include refreshing transparency on your elected officials; ranging from your Mayor, to N.C. House Representatives in Raleigh, to Congressmen and women and Senators in D.C. 

Number three: a section dedicated to the elementary steps related to participating in our democracy. Information that should be available to all citizens; which include helpful resources on knowing how to register, where to and when to vote; as well as all general information related to upcoming elections in your community.

… and finally – we empower and inspire our readers with a tool groundbreaking in its design, and unique to our product, and that is a little something we call: The North Carolina Scorecard.

In order to truly understand the North Carolina Scorecard, we must take a step back in time.

This entire campaign really has its roots in another campaign; that of Entrepreneur and Political Candidate, Andrew Yang. Andrew Yang had a vision for the future which among other qualities, sought for us to see ourselves not simply as means to economic ends, but as human beings with intrinsic value, nuance, complexity, and strength. 

He believed that when you measure something, you implicitly set your policy goals.

Traditionally, our economy has been measured by looking at, essentially, two numbers: the gross domestic product (GDP) or the stock market. Employment rates and household income are also used to measure how the average worker is doing. 

However, even the creator of the GDP admits that it doesn’t really reflect the full story. And, as economic inequality rises and the fruits of society’s labors accrue to fewer individuals, it’s become obvious that we need to expand our definition of economic prosperity past a single number. The bottom 80% of Americans only own 8% of stocks and rising GDP has virtually no relationship with each citizen's wellbeing.

By focusing our measurement on GDP, we’ve promoted production over all else. It’s time to start measuring economic prosperity using a wider index that measures human as well as monetary indicators, such as:

  • Access to Education 
  • Affordability of Living 
  • Childhood Success Rates
  • Consumer and Student Debt
  • Economic Mobility 
  • Environmental Quality 
  • Felony Rehabilitation 
  • Freedom from Substance Abuse
  • Happiness Index 
  • Health-Adjusted Life Expectancy 
  • Income Inequality
  • Infant Mortality 
  • Marriage and Divorce Rates 
  • National Optimism 
  • Quality of Infrastructure 
  • Quality of Life 
  • Underemployment 
  • Veterans Security
  • Volunteerism
  • Work and Civic Engagement Levels 

In short, why use GDP as a proxy for how Americans (& North Carolinians) are doing when we can easily measure that well-being directly? Help us here at Cardinal Chronicles launch our magazine publication, and inside of each magazine; our readers will find information on local political news, and the reports on the actions and inactions of your representatives as well as the constantly updated, county-focused chronicle of the North Carolina Scorecard.  

Cardinal Cosmos

We knew from the very beginning that in order to best bring the vision of Cardinal Chronicles to reality, we would need to rely on new and exciting strategies. Our solution to inadequate data sources on non-traditional and human-centered indicators, was in time revealed to be none other than the invention of the most productive and game-changing phone app you've never thought of. Cardinal Cosmos is the name of Cardinal Chronicles' very own phone app (in pre-development currently). Cardinal Cosmos will be free to download from the App Store, and will work in a simple way:

An individual will download our phone app, and after answering a few basic questions (ie., which county are you a residence of, what's your age, race, gender), they will be met with a tailored series of polls, and surveys, specific to the issues most relevant to their daily lives. These interactive elements in the app will be updated weekly, and will provide for Cardinal Chronicles, the perfect resource in supplementing our orthodox institutional data sources. Don't let your voice go unheard - support this campaign and help bring Cardinal Cosmos to reality. 

By Supporting This Campaign

  • By supporting this campaign: you are aiding in an emerging renaissance in political science. By equipping even the most apolitical folk with direct and digestible information on the actions of their government, you are contributing to the mending of one of the most mangled and broken pieces in our democracy, and that is government accountability.
  • By supporting this campaign: you are making history, by helping bring forward a new frontier in the field of public data polling. Through the power of technology, we have designed a system which allows for the direct supplication of traditional data sources, with real-time responses on issues that real people care about.
  • By supporting this campaign: you are bestowing upon your fellow statesmen the incredible gift of education. A magazine which can be viewed for free in condensed monthly email broadcasts – versus bi-weekly publications. A magazine that will fill the dangerous void of misinformation and lack of transparency; a magazine that will serve as the ultimate indicator and tool in our universal bipartisan pursuit of positive change in the communities we call home. 

Every dollar you give, will be a dollar put towards bringing this resource to every man, woman and child in our beautiful State. 

We Need Your Help to Launch

You may be wondering what it is, exactly, that we need funding for? What all goes into launching a company of this variety, and where exactly will my contributions go towards? 

  • The primary expense in launching Cardinal Chronicles, and making it operational, rests in the development of our phone app - Cardinal Cosmos. Depending on factors that are still in the process of being worked out, Cosmos could cost anywhere between $25,000 - $40,000 to develop. 
  • Furthermore, there are maintenance costs associated with a start-up company, including insuring we always have the company capital needed to ensure timely distribution of new magazine publications to all subscribers. Similar expenses include data source acquiring, as well as printing and shipping fees.
  • The design of Cardinal Chronicles is (in the most ideal perspective in my mind), built like clockwork, and with the pieces all aligned, should function as one with the needs and wants of its customers, as well as with the profit needs associated with survival and ample room for the addition of new counties and expansion of operations. Regardless, the more safety net we have to fall back on, the sooner we'll be able to advance into full operational business. 

In terms of the 5 donation based levels connected with this campaign; these serve as incentives to those with the ability and willingness to donate at or above certain thresholds. All contributors to Cardinal Chronicles are appreciated greatly, and will receive personalized thank you messages from me, on behalf of the Company. Furthermore, I would be more than happy to keep all contributors posted on any and all updates related to the campaign. 

Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

If this campaign does not meet its goal of $10k by the end of the fundraiser - fear not, every penny of the funds raised will go directly into advancing this now shared dream. I will make it a personal responsibility and privilege to keep all contributors up to date on the usage of their contributions, as well as on the state of the Company they had so generously believed in, as I have believed in it. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If contributing funds is something that is unavailable to you at the moment, then worry not - you can still help this campaign in a number of substantial ways!

By sharing this fundraiser to your friends and family on social media, you will be doing great work in seeing to it that more folk in our State be witness to this campaign. You can always help!  

Sincerely and humbly,

​Founder and President Zachary Jamison Allen.

story:
Short Summary

 

About Me

I am Naasu Fofanah, a Pentland Scholar, an International Development and Public Administration professional specializing in Gender & Global Public Policy. I also am the Founder of Susue Consultancy in Sierra Leone delivering Executive Policy Advisory, Training and Coaching services. 

Furthermore, I serve as Deputy Chairperson of Unity Party Sierra Leone intending to increase participation and representation of women in political party governance. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b37xTcxXvaY

In 2019, I was also elected Board Chairperson of the Sierra Leone Rugby Union and have succeeded in influencing gender parity reforms with 5 women 4 men; established the Women’s Rugby Advisory Committee and a minimum 30% women in the Executive. This attracted the attention of World Rugby  (https://www.world.rugby/news/435759?lang=en).

Previously, I served as Special Gender Adviser to the erstwhile President of Sierra Leone where I spearheaded innovative policy initiatives on Gender Equality and Women’s Empowerment. I consider myself an avid Women and Girls Advocate whose work contributes to the global policy discourse on gender issues.   

My Story

It is an honour to be able to share my incredible personal story via my book "Leave it Naasu - How to Take Charge and go for what you want."  

Born and raised in Sierra Leone, at age 23 I was lucky enough to flee the devastating civil war for the United Kingdom and the United States. Growing up in a single-parent household with scarce resources and very few opportunities was not easy for me and my siblings. As the eldest, responsibility for myself and family came early. From age 17. I found myself dealing with the burden of this responsibility coupled with the consequences of abuse and rape. I was determined to succeed despite the socio-economic status of my parents and numerous other obstacles.

I knew instinctively that education was the key to breaking that cycle and nothing was going to stand in my way. My educational achievements have been exceptional. I started university as an insecure 31-year single mother who was going through a very difficult time in 2001.

Today, I hold the following academic qualifications: Joint Executive Master of Public Administration – New York University (NYU Wagner) & University College London (2018) with full scholarship from Pentland; Master of Arts in Education, Gender & International Development – Institute of Education UCL (2005); Bachelor of Science (Hons)- University of Westminster (2004)     

In Sierra Leone, I have contributed immensely to public policy reforms by spearheading the most transformative gender policy agenda on national policy.

As the only female pillar Lead for the development of the National five-year strategy - Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper (PRSP 2013-2018), I successfully advocated and lobbied to have this historic initiative to have a separate pillar on Gender Equality and Women's Empowerment. This move led to increased awareness including 4% more funding from the government to the Gender Ministry coupled with more financial and programme support from development partners.

An Authoritative Voice

I have an authoritative voice on key women's rights issues in my country and globally. For example, as a rape survivor, I have been courageous in sharing my story to my country and the world which has encouraged other women and girls to openly talk about their ordeals. Through my 50th speaker series advocacy platform, I have addressed and engaged 16 schools and approximately 13000 students in Sierra Leone and Ghana. My goal is to support girls who are victims while sharing preventive strategies to those at risks.

The decision to finally write my book came from the experiences of sharing my story with schools in 2019. The questions and appetite to hear more about how I overcame the hurdles from both boys and girls finally helped me to break the culture of not writing.  They have been my motivation and I am determined to make this book available to as many schools as possible all over the world. Your pledges would make this a reality for me and many children.       

Sharing My Story

However, writing and publishing a book requires commitment, enthusiasm and determination to achieve its objectives. Financing could be a huge impediment; therefore, I have decided to invite you to support me overcome this challenge my backing me on this mission.

My journey and the strategies to overcoming obstacles and how to succeed would be shared in this book as a testament of determination, resilience and humanity. Sharing my story is important because my experiences, unfortunately, remain the norm for millions of women and girls in developing countries and especially in Africa.

The number of female authors from developing countries is still relatively low. Few women from my country write books and those who do, mostly shy away from sharing personal experiences to avoid negative judgements. Furthermore, the reading culture is extremely limited in many developing countries including Sierra Leone. My wish is to increase the number of writers to facilitate a reading culture in my country. I want my book to reach millions of school-age girls as a source of motivation while also establishing me as an author.  

Collaboration with Rethink Press

I have signed my contract with Rethink Press, an independent hybrid publisher specializing in working with entrepreneurs, coaches and independent consultants to get their businesses or self-help books written and published.  The Managing Editor is Lucy McCarraher and Joe Gregory is the Managing Publisher of Rethink Press whose work is of exceptional quality. The company is based in Norfolk, UK, with a global team. Rethink Press publishes all titles to Amazon.co.uk, Amazon.com, other Amazon territories where appropriate, and Amazon Kindle.  Rethink Press also distributes through the following wholesalers: Nielsen BookData, Bowker, BDS, Gardners, Ingram Books,

My Aim and Your Support

I aim to raise £10,000 which would go towards publishing, marketing and launching of the book. 

I want you to be part of my amazing journey and this is my invitation to join me.   

I would like to offer you the chance to invest in the book and my mission right from the start. Your pledge would collectively help change lives by making this book available to millions of people globally especially women and girls. Together, we can do this!

This is a mission to get this knowledge to the women who need it.

The more I can raise the more women I can help.

I cannot do it alone!
story_txt:
Short Summary
 
About Me
I am Naasu Fofanah, a Pentland Scholar, an International Development and Public Administration professional specializing in Gender & Global Public Policy. I also am the Founder of Susue Consultancy in Sierra Leone delivering Executive Policy Advisory, Training and Coaching services. 
Furthermore, I serve as Deputy Chairperson of Unity Party Sierra Leone intending to increase participation and representation of women in political party governance. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b37xTcxXvaY
In 2019, I was also elected Board Chairperson of the Sierra Leone Rugby Union and have succeeded in influencing gender parity reforms with 5 women 4 men; established the Women’s Rugby Advisory Committee and a minimum 30% women in the Executive. This attracted the attention of World Rugby  (https://www.world.rugby/news/435759?lang=en).
Previously, I served as Special Gender Adviser to the erstwhile President of Sierra Leone where I spearheaded innovative policy initiatives on Gender Equality and Women’s Empowerment. I consider myself an avid Women and Girls Advocate whose work contributes to the global policy discourse on gender issues.   
My Story
It is an honour to be able to share my incredible personal story via my book "Leave it Naasu - How to Take Charge and go for what you want."  
Born and raised in Sierra Leone, at age 23 I was lucky enough to flee the devastating civil war for the United Kingdom and the United States. Growing up in a single-parent household with scarce resources and very few opportunities was not easy for me and my siblings. As the eldest, responsibility for myself and family came early. From age 17. I found myself dealing with the burden of this responsibility coupled with the consequences of abuse and rape. I was determined to succeed despite the socio-economic status of my parents and numerous other obstacles.
I knew instinctively that education was the key to breaking that cycle and nothing was going to stand in my way. My educational achievements have been exceptional. I started university as an insecure 31-year single mother who was going through a very difficult time in 2001.
Today, I hold the following academic qualifications: Joint Executive Master of Public Administration – New York University (NYU Wagner) & University College London (2018) with full scholarship from Pentland; Master of Arts in Education, Gender & International Development – Institute of Education UCL (2005); Bachelor of Science (Hons)- University of Westminster (2004)     
In Sierra Leone, I have contributed immensely to public policy reforms by spearheading the most transformative gender policy agenda on national policy.
As the only female pillar Lead for the development of the National five-year strategy - Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper (PRSP 2013-2018), I successfully advocated and lobbied to have this historic initiative to have a separate pillar on Gender Equality and Women's Empowerment. This move led to increased awareness including 4% more funding from the government to the Gender Ministry coupled with more financial and programme support from development partners.
An Authoritative Voice
I have an authoritative voice on key women's rights issues in my country and globally. For example, as a rape survivor, I have been courageous in sharing my story to my country and the world which has encouraged other women and girls to openly talk about their ordeals. Through my 50th speaker series advocacy platform, I have addressed and engaged 16 schools and approximately 13000 students in Sierra Leone and Ghana. My goal is to support girls who are victims while sharing preventive strategies to those at risks.
The decision to finally write my book came from the experiences of sharing my story with schools in 2019. The questions and appetite to hear more about how I overcame the hurdles from both boys and girls finally helped me to break the culture of not writing.  They have been my motivation and I am determined to make this book available to as many schools as possible all over the world. Your pledges would make this a reality for me and many children.       
Sharing My Story
However, writing and publishing a book requires commitment, enthusiasm and determination to achieve its objectives. Financing could be a huge impediment; therefore, I have decided to invite you to support me overcome this challenge my backing me on this mission.
My journey and the strategies to overcoming obstacles and how to succeed would be shared in this book as a testament of determination, resilience and humanity. Sharing my story is important because my experiences, unfortunately, remain the norm for millions of women and girls in developing countries and especially in Africa.
The number of female authors from developing countries is still relatively low. Few women from my country write books and those who do, mostly shy away from sharing personal experiences to avoid negative judgements. Furthermore, the reading culture is extremely limited in many developing countries including Sierra Leone. My wish is to increase the number of writers to facilitate a reading culture in my country. I want my book to reach millions of school-age girls as a source of motivation while also establishing me as an author.  
Collaboration with Rethink Press
I have signed my contract with Rethink Press, an independent hybrid publisher specializing in working with entrepreneurs, coaches and independent consultants to get their businesses or self-help books written and published.  The Managing Editor is Lucy McCarraher and Joe Gregory is the Managing Publisher of Rethink Press whose work is of exceptional quality. The company is based in Norfolk, UK, with a global team. Rethink Press publishes all titles to Amazon.co.uk, Amazon.com, other Amazon territories where appropriate, and Amazon Kindle.  Rethink Press also distributes through the following wholesalers: Nielsen BookData, Bowker, BDS, Gardners, Ingram Books,
My Aim and Your Support
I aim to raise £10,000 which would go towards publishing, marketing and launching of the book. 
I want you to be part of my amazing journey and this is my invitation to join me.   
I would like to offer you the chance to invest in the book and my mission right from the start. Your pledge would collectively help change lives by making this book available to millions of people globally especially women and girls. Together, we can do this!
This is a mission to get this knowledge to the women who need it.
The more I can raise the more women I can help.
I cannot do it alone!

story:
MyLifeasaCrazyAlky

A True Story of Alcoholism, Deceit, Loss and Tragedy

 

Excerpts from Chapter 1:  The Heartache

"When not used as directed, alcohol can seep into the fiber of the best people
regardless of age, status, gender, ethnicity, intelligence or financial means.  And when it takes hold, it lays claim to everything that we humans hold dear. 

"I drank for immediate relief from devastation.  I drank to remove myself from thoughts of a loving relationship that would never be.  I drank to sleep, to stop thinking about how unlovable and unloved I was.  I drank to forget about my terrible life as a 26-year-old woman without a husband, or even a partner.  I drank to feel something ferocious in my mouth and body.  After all, I was weak, and I required something with enough power to remove me from my world of consciousness, at least for a few hours.  Alcohol officially became my best friend, on the way to evolving into my worst enemy."  

 -Dawn Marie Stratton

 

The insidious disease of alcoholism threatens the loss of so many precious things – career, home, family, friends, health, financial security, dignity, and most significantly, self-respect.  I nearly lost all of these life essentials, and more.  

My name is Dawn Marie Stratton, and I am an alcoholic.  But most of all, I am a survivor and living proof that the lonely, dangerous, heart wrenching disease that is alcoholism, though never cured, can be conquered. 

I have published the first two chapters of my wild and shocking story at www.mylifeasacrazyalky.com  so that you or someone you know may begin to understand what it's really like to be an alcoholic and to have your life spiral out of control. The good news is, everything can be returned in time, and sometimes the most devastating moments in our lives can also be the ones that lead us to paradise.  

 

My Story Will Inspire Others

My goal is to publish My Life as a Crazy Alky in both ebook and as well as hard copy formats by October 2016.  In addition to selling my book online for a nominal price, I also plan to print hard copies of my memoir so that individuals without the luxury of technology will be able to read the story of how I overcame decades of addiction. 

Should I meet my goal of raising $50,000, I will publish my complete memoirs online and print 10,000 hard copies.  I will also travel to various shelters and meetings across the country to speak to others about finding their way to sobriety.  With your help I will be able to not only promote and publish my memoirs, but hopefully, contribute to helping many souls avoid the hell that was my life for nearly two decades.  

 

Alcohol is Responsible for  189,000 Emergency-room Visits and 4,300 Deaths Annually 

Definition of Alcoholism:  A chronic disease characterized by uncontrolled drinking and preoccupation with alcohol 

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports that over time, excessive alcohol use can lead to serious, often incurable health problems, including:

Chronic diseases
High blood pressure, heart disease, stroke, liver disease and digestive problems, in addition to cancer of the breast, mouth, throat, esophagus, liver, and colon

Learning/memory problems
Dementia and poor school performance among students

Mental health problems
Depression and anxiety

Social problems
Lost productivity, family problems and unemployment

 

ALCOHOLICS CONTINUE TO DRINK, DESPITE THE FOLLOWING:

-  Failure to fulfill major obligations at work, school, or home

-  Recurrent use in situations where it is hazardous (such as driving a car or operating machinery)

-  Legal problems

-  Having medical, social, family, or interpersonal problems caused by or worsened by drinking

Alcoholics continue to drink to attain the feeling of euphoria they first experienced when they started drinking.

 

Our Desperate Stories are Life Lessons 

I am no doctor, but I am highly proficient in an alcoholic lifestyle and the devastation that it leaves in its wake.  Please visit www.mylifeasacrazyalky.com to read the first two chapters of my book, in which I describe my heartbreaking fall into full-blown alcoholism, resulting in one of the most embarrassing moments of my adult life.  My tragic story was almost as difficult to write as it was to live, yet it is the latest of my accomplishments in sobriety.  I continue to soldier on.

I invite you to share your most embarrassing alcoholic moment with me via Facebook or Twitter, or email me at dawn@mylifeasacrazyalky.com.  I’d love to hear from you!

story:
In an age where online ‘sharing’ is a conversation starter, we want to take it back to the old-school. We want you to share your copy of Ethos with your friends and family; we want you to share the stories that you have read in Ethos magazine with the people you meet in the pub, the passenger next to you on the bus. We want Ethos to be full of photos of the people who make these stories possible. Ethos is rooted in community, and we’re feeding our community of like-minded readers across the globe.

A printed magazine means a welcome break from your screen; it means that, as a reader, you can take your time to absorb its stories. It means that you can appreciate the beauty of the entire page in one glance.

But, most importantly, a printed magazine means that the incredible stories of these ethical businesses live on. They live on bookshelves, on coffee tables and on night stands; in today’s online world – even the best stories are lost at the refresh of a page.

Ethos is a quarterly magazine covering stories of ethical entrepreneurship, innovation, sustainability and socially responsible business. We look at the good businesses around us – large and small – and tell their stories. They’re makers and manufacturers, food producers and micro-funders; shops and services. They’re the people, products and experiences that touch our lives, every day.

We’re a small team of writers, journalists, and filmmakers based in Liverpool, UK. As a Community Interest Company (CIC), Ethos works closely with the local community and further afield, to tell the stories and raise awareness of the hidden business networks that are helping our towns and cities to thrive. We're making the most of our connections, to affect real change in the community.

We launched Ethos online in the summer of 2015; during that time, we’ve built up tens of thousands of readers in 106 countries, and a database of more than 12,000 people. Our first film generated 10,000 views in its first week. But, there’s something magical about flicking through a beautiful, printed magazine with delightful design and thought-provoking stories. So we’re crowdfunding, to print our first editions.

The face of business is changing. Advances in technology and the internet have opened up conversations between a global community of thought leaders and change makers, allowing them to collaborate on some of the most pressing issues of our time. Collaboration between companies big and small is becoming the norm, to reach a sustainable end goal which benefits people and the planet, irrespective of profits. We buy locally; and we also pick and choose people around the world who do things for the right reasons. We’re looking for different values.

Business is more than a dog-eat-dog mentality; it’s no longer encapsulated by the ‘rat-race’ or the sterile high-rise office block. Today’s business is vibrant; it’s colourful; and most importantly, today’s business has human interaction at its core.

Our world is full of amazing people achieving brilliant things; being responsible, inspiring people, employing people and changing things for the better. Sometimes they’re tiny organisations on your doorstep; sometimes they’re global brands who’ve been around far longer than any of us. These are the stories of the things they do. Bold and brave, innovative and surprising, they’re the people doing things differently.

We’ve spoken to some of the world’s most influential businesses; from global clothing giant Adidas, to sustainable, family-run makers and manufacturers. Our stories come from the heart of the community; from the Detroit Eastern Market Corporation to online marketplace Etsy. We follow global movements, such as the Awesome Foundation and Parley for the Oceans, which are just two of the organisations changing our business world, for good. They all have a story to tell. Ethos tells that story.

 

Andrew Beattie - Managing Director - Ethos's managing director, Andrew has worked with startup businesses and grassroots organisations for most of his career. His work includes finding local, national and international grassroots networks and connecting them together to share ideas, innovations and stories. Andrew co-founded the City Tribune, an independent pop-up newspaper which was distributed to 50,000 people at the inaugural, International Festival of Business in 2014. @AndrewBeattie

Lucy Chesters - Editor - A freelance writer and editor, Lucy is responsible for collating Ethos's editorial content. Trustee of the Liverpool chapter of the Awesome Foundation, Lucy is involved in local business and cultural networks. @lucychesters

Fiona Shaw - Publisher - Ethos publisher Fiona is an award-winning copywriter and journalist, and director of publishing company Wordscapes. She specialises in non-fiction storytelling and developing powerful, authentic narratives for the business and lifestyle sectors. Fiona is the co-founder of the City Tribune and the Chair of Open Culture, UK based arts organisation. @wearewordscapes

Patrick Hurley - Operations Manager - Patrick works in social and civic innovation, promoting the growth of organisations that benefit their local community. An elected member of Liverpool City Council, Patrick  also works in the social enterprise network. @patrick_hurley

Allan Melia - Head of Film - Allan is a camera operator and editor with a background in independent  and commercial films. Allan films, edits and produces all of Ethos's film content. @Allan_Melia

We are looking for £20,000 to fund the first print edition of Ethos magazine. The money pays for the design, print and distribution of our first editions; it will allow us to pay our wonderful writers and collaborators, and enable them to carry on researching and unearthing the inspiring stories of business and ethical entrepreneurship happening around the world.

We’re also looking to produce a series of film content throughout the year, ranging from short documentaries, to interviews and extended stories from our print editions. We want the stories of the people that we meet to reach as many new audiences as possible, wherever they may be in the world. There are some stories which just need to be told through film.

We’ve also set aside a chunk of our budget for social media and online sharing; we want to share stories with the biggest number of people that we can, so what we do will always have a digital element. We’ll work at creating an online community which you’re a part of – so you can share stories with like-minded people, and we can spread the word about the good stuff people are doing.

We’re offering a range of rewards for the people who want to support us on our crowdfunding journey. Ethos is something we want you to be a part of, so it includes everything from our eternal gratitude on social media, to deals on magazine issues and subscriptions. And you can join our team for a series of workshops, based around some of the themes in the magazine. We’ve joined up with a number of ethical and sustainable brands, who are producing limited edition ‘Ethos’ creations.

We are also offering bulk orders of Ethos Magazine and Ethos subscriptions. If you're a school, university, cafe, coworking space or speciality bookshop; or you're just looking to bulk order our magazine - we'll be really happy to hear from you; let us know via the comments section and we can arrange something with you.


Between us, we’ve worked in publishing and media for more years than we care to tot up. So we’re aware of some of the technical and publishing challenges that lie ahead. The biggest risk, from your point of view, is that we only get part of the money. What happens then?

Well, we know what our absolute minimum cost is to get the magazines out there. And we’re committed to using the crowdfunding to kick-start our print runs. We’re already talking to a number of carefully-chosen advertisers who’re keen to get involved – but they want to see the magazine. So we’re confident that, once we’ve got an issue to show them, advertising will cover our production costs – that’s what we’ve based our numbers on. We just need your help to get started.

Raising awareness of the stories that Ethos Magazine covers is one of our main objectives, so if you could take a couple of minutes to share our campaign on social media, we would be very grateful...

Have you got a story that would be perfect for Ethos Magazine? We’d love to hear from you! Drop our editor, Lucy a line at lucy.chesters [at] ethospaper.com and tell us more about your story...

If you have any further questions about Ethos Magazine, or about our campaign then please let us know in the comments section...

story:
Who am I?

Furrowed brows, bulging eyeballs, stuttering like a bad engine that just won't start! - some of the responses I receive when I introduce myself with my long African name, Abimbola Akinmade -yes, that's me. And I am the author of 'Say my Name'. 

What is this book about?

This book is about a witty young girl of Nigerian origin, but raised in the UK, and her amusing quest to find a cure to tongue-tangulosis (an adverse reaction to all names different), and save all of the beautiful, musical, meaningful names. 

It is dedicated to adults and children alike from all over the world; beautiful people with beautiful names that are long and twisted, like ripe vines reaching towards the sun. 

 

Why is this campaign important?

This campaign is important because 'Say my Name' is a story that needs to be heard, and that so many can relate to.  I grew up disliking my name ever since I started primary school, and my teacher went bright red whilst trying to pronounce it in front of the class. It was that day, I learnt that what was normal to me was strange to everyone else. My name just didn't quite fit in, and because of that, I felt ashamed. 

Now that I'm older, have travelled and experienced different cultures. I recognize the beauty in my Nigerian name, and grow more connected to my heritage with each passing day.  I recognize that my name is a gift rather than a burden. And I want all children to recognize this too.

Your name is a link to your heritage so take pride in it. LOVE IT. LIVE IT. OWN IT. 

Where do your contributions go?

Your contributions will go towards marketing and production costs, as well as printing hundreds of books to be donated for free to:

  • Schools
  • Libraries
  • NGO's 

in and around London, Nigeria and potentially Colombia (if enough funds are raised).

The aim is to spread this positive message and make this book accessible to children in our community for free!

Campaign perks 

NOTE- TO RECEIVE PERKS YOU NEED TO PLACE AN ORDER VIA 'GET PERK' AND NOT A DONATION 

In return for your contributions are various perks, like:

  • Say my Name bookmarks (x2 designs)

  • Paperback copies of the book (8*10)

  • Names featured in the opening pages of the printed book 

  • and Private book readings   

How do I submit my name/s?

Contributors will be contacted via the email addresses they provide when checking out. Please keep an eye out for this email from readwithmeafrica@gmail.com. 

Other ways you can help!

Your contributions are key to sharing this book with the community, but if for any reason you cannot contribute- fear not!! Sharing, posting, and talking about this campaign with your family and friends is invaluable and would be truly appreciated.

Visit @ReadWithMeAfrica on facebook to nominate schools, NGO's, and libraries that you feel could really benefit from the donations. 

When will I get my perks?

All perks will be delivered within 3 months from the end of this campaign.
story_txt:
Who am I?Furrowed brows, bulging eyeballs, stuttering like a bad engine that just won't start! - some of the responses I receive when I introduce myself with my long African name, Abimbola Akinmade -yes, that's me. And I am the author of 'Say my Name'. What is this book about?This book is about a witty young girl of Nigerian origin, but raised in the UK, and her amusing quest to find a cure to tongue-tangulosis (an adverse reaction to all names different), and save all of the beautiful, musical, meaningful names. It is dedicated to adults and children alike from all over the world; beautiful people with beautiful names that are long and twisted, like ripe vines reaching towards the sun.  Why is this campaign important?This campaign is important because 'Say my Name' is a story that needs to be heard, and that so many can relate to.  I grew up disliking my name ever since I started primary school, and my teacher went bright red whilst trying to pronounce it in front of the class. It was that day, I learnt that what was normal to me was strange to everyone else. My name just didn't quite fit in, and because of that, I felt ashamed. Now that I'm older, have travelled and experienced different cultures. I recognize the beauty in my Nigerian name, and grow more connected to my heritage with each passing day.  I recognize that my name is a gift rather than a burden. And I want all children to recognize this too.Your name is a link to your heritage so take pride in it. LOVE IT. LIVE IT. OWN IT. Where do your contributions go?Your contributions will go towards marketing and production costs, as well as printing hundreds of books to be donated for free to:

Say my Name bookmarks (x2 designs)

Names featured in the opening pages of the printed book 
and Private book readings   How do I submit my name/s?Contributors will be contacted via the email addresses they provide when checking out. Please keep an eye out for this email from readwithmeafrica@gmail.com. Other ways you can help!Your contributions are key to sharing this book with the community, but if for any reason you cannot contribute- fear not!! story:
Short Summary

  • I’m Stewart C. Alastair. I spent 10 years working for lawyers and there I became a published writer as a Legal Assistant.
  • This campaign is important not only for me but for those who will read these books. I believe Bible believing Christians are about to become the outcasts of the world. Christianity will be on trial once church pastors give in to ecumenism; that is the gathering of all religions under one Universal doctrine.
  • As much as this campaign will assist me in publishing my books, I believe that the greater benefit will be for those that read my books. As Christians become increasingly the bane of society, this book foreshadows that process.

What We Need & What You Get

  • After looking at the cost of publishing physical books, I calculated exactly the amount that would need to be raised. $1781.00 will be enough for self-publishing the remaining two books in this series.
  • For various pledge amounts you will receive:
    • Damon Black Trilogy t-shirt.
    • A 99¢ cent Amazon code for Book II.
  • Each dollar pledged will go to creating three things:  
    • The Book Interior design.
    • The cover art.
    • A special edition of Book II, which will contain bonus material.
      • Q and A section.
      • Chapter 1 of Book III.

The Impact

  • Your contribution to this project will reach both Christians and non-Christians from all different backgrounds.
  • The success of publishing Book I was a minor achievement. But the following two books will be the crowning achievement.
  • With the “99¢ perk” contributors will be able to purchase books for friends and family at a fraction of the usual cost.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you can’t contribute financially, there are other things that are equally important:
    • First and foremost, PRAYER!
    • Second, tell a friend about the Damon Black Trilogy and that they can buy Book I on Amazon or GooglePlay right now!
    • Third, if you read my books and like them, please put a good review on Amazon or Google.
    • Last, please…pretty please use the Indiegogo share tools!

Short Summary

I’m Stewart C. Alastair. I spent 10 years working for lawyers and there I became a published writer as a Legal Assistant.
This campaign is important not only for me but for those who will read these books. I believe Bible believing Christians are about to become the outcasts of the world. Christianity will be on trial once church pastors give in to ecumenism; that is the gathering of all religions under one Universal doctrine.
As much as this campaign will assist me in publishing my books, I believe that the greater benefit will be for those that read my books. As Christians become increasingly the bane of society, this book foreshadows that process.

What We Need & What You Get

After looking at the cost of publishing physical books, I calculated exactly the amount that would need to be raised. $1781.00 will be enough for self-publishing the remaining two books in this series.
For various pledge amounts you will receive:
Damon Black Trilogy t-shirt.
A 99¢ cent Amazon code for Book II.


Each dollar pledged will go to creating three things:  
The Book Interior design.
The cover art.
A special edition of Book II, which will contain bonus material.
Q and A section.
Chapter 1 of Book III.





The Impact

Your contribution to this project will reach both Christians and non-Christians from all different backgrounds.
The success of publishing Book I was a minor achievement. But the following two books will be the crowning achievement. 

With the “99¢ perk” contributors will be able to purchase books for friends and family at a fraction of the usual cost.

Other Ways You Can Help
If you can’t contribute financially, there are other things that are equally important:
First and foremost, PRAYER!
Second, tell a friend about the Damon Black Trilogy and that they can buy Book I on Amazon or GooglePlay right now!
Third, if you read my books and like them, please put a good review on Amazon or Google.
Last, please…pretty please use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
La raccolta fondi online è terminata. Poichè abbiamo ricevuto molte più donazioni via Bonifico Bancario, manteniamo aperta solo questa modalità. Leggendo di seguito trovi i dati bancari.

PERCHE' UNA APP DI ARCHEOLOGIA E TURISMO INDUSTRIALE A GENOVA

  1. per promuovere la valorizzazione e/o un riuso illuminato dei luoghi simbolo del patrimonio e della storia del lavoro e dell'industria della città
  2. perchè valorizzando questi luoghi, possiamo ampliare l'offerta turistica locale, strutturando percorsi alla scoperta della storia e della cultura industriali della città, la quale ebbe un importante ruolo a livello nazionale ed internazionale;
  3. perchè così facendo, possiamo portare Genova ad occupare il posto che le spetta  nel panorama internazionale di valorizzazione del patrimonio e del turismo industriale: un settore in espansione e sempre maggiormente riconosciuto in Europa, negli Stati Uniti e in Australia...
  4. e potremo inserire questi percorsi all'interno di circuiti internazionali che promuovono il turismo e la storia industriali, come l'ERIH.

---

    FASI DI PROGETTO
    Primo passo dello sviluppo della app sarà quello di mappare il percorso Di molo in Molo.** 
    Successivamente, la app allargherà la mappatura e gli approfondimenti ad altre, selezionate aree di interesse del patrimonio industriale dell’area metropolitana genovese.

    Vorremmo via via mappare altre importanti aree della storia del lavoro e della cultura dell'industria nella nostra città - anche al fine di poter poi promuovere una loro valorizzazione o loro riuso illuminato.

    Per farlo, chiediamo anche il tuo aiuto, con una donazione libera.

    ---

    COME FARE UNA DONAZIONE LIBERA 

    La raccolta fondi online è terminata. Poichè abbiamo ricevuto molte più donazioni via Bonifico Bancario, manteniamo aperta solo questa modalità. Ecco i dati di seguito:

    Beneficiario: inGE Associazione
    IBAN: IT 41 S 02008 01400 000103591622;
    Causale: Donazione Industrial Genoa App - Cognome e Nome

    Grazie! Seguici su Facebook e Instagram per aggiornamenti!

    ---

    DISTRIBUZIONE e PREZZO AL PUBBLICO
    Download gratis da Apple Store e Google Play.

    --

    ** STORIA DELLA GUIDA "DI MOLO IN MOLO"

    La guida nasce dalle ricerche e dagli studi, cominciate dagli anni Duemila, promossi dalla ex-Soprintendenza Beni Storici Artistici Etnoantropologici della Liguria (oggi Archeologia Belle Arti e Paesaggio) del Ministero dei Beni e delle Attività Culturali e del Turismo, sul patrimonio industriale conservato nel Porto Antico di Genova, dopo le grandi trasformazioni scaturite e create dall’Esposizione Colombiana del 1992.

    Questa attività ha portato a far conoscere a centinaia di persone, con visite guidate e conferenze, la storia del porto di Genova attraverso la visione diretta di ciò che è conservato della sua storia e ha fatto sì che fosse creato, a coronamento del Museo del Mare, il Galata, il Galata Open Air Museum, presso le banchine della Darsena municipale.

    Il successo  e la curiosità suscitata da queste iniziative ha poi portato a voler creare qualcosa che aiutasse a capire meglio quanto si raccontava nelle passeggiate lungo i moli.

    ---

    ** COSA E’ DI MOLO IN MOLO

    Di Molo in Molo è un percorso volto ad accompagnare i visitatori del Porto Antico in una passeggiata alla scoperta delle tracce di ciò che è stata per Genova l’area oggi denominata Porto Antico - prima delle grandi trasformazioni degli anni Novanta del secolo scorso, che da spazio operativo portuale è stata trasformata in parte integrante e vitale del tessuto urbano.

    Vi si parlerà del porto ottocentesco, con i suoi mezzi e attrezzature, senza trascurare quanto è ancor oggi visibile della città antica, passeggiando fra banchine e vecchi moli alla ricerca delle tracce di quella rete di manufatti che hanno connotato la vita di lavoro e di fatica della più grande fabbrica della città.

    Nella guida si illustrano il porto otto-novecentesco, con i suoi edifici, i mezzi e le attrezzature; quanto è ancora conservato della città antica. Una passeggiata fra calate e vecchi moli per scoprire quanto ancora del vecchio porto è presente fra le calate e i pontili.

    ---

    HASHTAG
    #dimoloinmolo #industrialgenoa #inGE

    ---

    CHI E' inGE

    Nata nel Giugno del 2015, inGE è l'Associazione per la Promozione e la Diffusione della Cultura e del Patrimonio Industriale a Genova e in Liguria.  Fondata da tre esperti di patrimonio e percorsi industriali con ampie esperienze all'estero nel settore, si pone al servizio del territorio perché possa occupare il posto che gli spetta nel panorama internazionale dell'archeologia e del turismo industriale: settori in espansione in Europa, negli Stati Uniti e in Australia. Settori volti a valorizzare il passato industriale ed intenderlo come possibile risorsa. inGE crede che la valorizzazione del patrimonio ligure e genovese debba includere il suo passato industriale, il quale ha avuto un ruolo fondamentale a livello locale, nazionale ed internazionale. Per questo, si pone come obiettivo quello di attivare sul territorio genovese e ligure iniziative e percorsi volti a valorizzare il patrimonio industriale locale; e a diffondere ed incentivare la cultura dell'industria, dell'architettura industriale e delle produzioni locali.
